alert_body: Severe thunderstorm and flood watches issued, fueled by intense humidity
text: Severe thunderstorms could be capable of producing flooding rain, damaging winds and dangerous lightning. Storms are expected to be most numerous between 2 and 7 p.m.

alert_body: Fed leaves interest rates unchanged but warns about risks of inflation and slower growth
text: Six months after the Federal Reserve hit pause on interest-rate cuts, the central bank remains firmly in wait-and-see mode as it gauges the fallout from President Donald Trump’s trade war and other policies.

alert_body: Karen Read was found not guilty of killing police officer boyfriend John O’Keefe, a year after first case ended in a mistrial
text: Read’s dramatic and complex case divided a Massachusetts community and drew national attention. Prosecutors alleged she hit O’Keefe with her car after an argument. Her lawyers argued she was framed in a law enforcement cover-up.

alert_body: State Department to require visa-seeking students to make social media accounts public for scrutiny of anti-U.S. sentiments
text: The State Department is restarting interviews for new student visas and planning to review online posts for hostility toward the United States, according to a cable sent to embassies and consulates Wednesday and obtained by The Washington Post. The move comes after the department suspended foreign students’ visa appointments last month in what it described as a move against universities allegedly fostering antisemitism and other national security issues.

alert_body: ‘I’m just so scared’: Lawmakers reckon with safety after Minnesota slayings
text: Safety concerns are already prompting lawmakers to change the way they live, especially in places like Minnesota, which has a civic culture that promotes close contact with constituents.

alert_body: We asked 1,000 Americans if they support U.S. strikes on Iran. Here’s what they said.
text: A Washington Post flash poll finds Americans opposing U.S. airstrikes against Iran by a 20 percentage-point margin — 45 percent to 25 percent. A sizable 30 percent said they are unsure.

alert_body: Iranian attack hits key Israeli hospital, medical center and IDF say
text: The strike caused “extensive damage” in several areas of the Soroka Medical Center, the hospital said. Iran said it was targeting military and intelligence headquarters near the hospital. Israeli Defense Minister Israel Katz said he instructed the Israeli military to “intensify strikes against strategic targets in Iran and government sites in Tehran,” in retaliation. Israeli police reported no casualties but said there was property damage.

alert_body: Trump’s ultimatum. Social media checks. Transgender care. Social Security. Karen Read. Heat wave. Longevity test. Catch up now.

text: Play now to earn your Thursday points.

alert_body: How 280,000 eggs were stolen in America’s scramble over prices and profit
text: The shipment from egg giant Cal-Maine was supposed to travel from Maryland to Florida. Then came a ransom note from the supposed trucker: “You need to zelle or wire $7500 if you want your eggs.”

alert_body: Is the American Dream still alive? Test your knowledge of generational mobility with this quiz.
text: There is widespread skepticism that the American Dream is still possible. Is it?

text: Carolyn Hax: Grieving a beloved dog is hard. The guilt is making it worse.

alert_body: Trump will make a decision on striking Iran within two weeks, sees opportunity for negotiations first, White House says
text: Trump’s statement Thursday, delivered by White House spokeswoman Karoline Leavitt, extends the timeline for a decision from days to weeks. In what she said was a direct quote from Trump, the president cited “a substantial chance of negotiations that may or may not take place with Iran in the near future.”

alert_body: Severe thunderstorm watch in effect until 9 p.m.
text: Storms capable of producing damaging winds and dangerous lightning are expected to come through the Beltway area between about 4 and 7 p.m. A flood watch is also in effect because of the possibility of torrential rain.

alert_body: Have knee pain? Here’s what really works.
text: Knee braces, hydrotherapy and exercise are some of the most effective ways to address arthritis-related knee pain and stiffness, a new study shows.

alert_body: How the Minnesota shooting suspect was found: A driver spotted a man hiding and waved down an officer
text: Interviews with witnesses, victims’ friends and people who know the suspect, along with court records, provide an account of the days leading up to the attacks and more than 40-plus hour search for the suspect that followed.

alert_body: Trump allowed to keep California National Guard in Los Angeles, appeals court rules
text: A federal appeals court in San Francisco said that President Donald Trump appears to have lawfully deployed the California National Guard in Los Angeles without consulting the state’s Gov. Gavin Newsom (D), delivering a win for the president as he aims to use the military to police protests against his deportation efforts.

alert_body: Trump’s decision. Dodger Stadium. Threats to lawmakers. Listeria outbreak. Plastic bag fees. Roman puzzle. ‘Jaws.’ Catch up now.

text: Think you’ve got what it takes to earn a perfect score? Take today’s longer news quiz and complete your point total for the week.

alert_body: Judge orders release of Columbia protester Mahmoud Khalil after months in ICE detention
text: Khalil, a prominent leader in campus protests over the war in Gaza, was the first high-profile noncitizen activist to be detained by the Trump administration as part of a crackdown on alleged antisemitism.

alert_body: Hundreds of U.S. citizens have fled Iran amid Israeli strikes, State Department says
text: In a private diplomatic bulletin obtained by The Washington Post, U.S. government officials acknowledge that many Americans are in harm’s way as President Donald Trump contemplates ordering military action against Iran.

alert_body: Conservation group's $60 million deal ends years-long fight over proposed mine near North America’s largest blackwater swamp
text: The nonprofit Conservation Fund said it would acquire thousands of acres of land outside Georgia's Okefenokee Swamp, one of the South's last truly wild places. The agreement halts a plan for a titanium mine that had been the subject of years of legal and political battles.

alert_body: A farmer put faith in Trump to protect him and the migrant he hired. Now he’s struggling to pay the bills.
text: With grants canceled and billions of dollars in jeopardy, President Donald Trump’s cuts are devastating American farmers and plunging families into uncertainty.

alert_body: Ask Sahaj: My brother’s getting married, and my ‘volatile’ mom is getting meaner.
text: Ask Sahaj: My brother’s getting married, and my ‘volatile’ mom is getting meaner.

alert_body: ‘Multiple’ B-2 bombers head west over Pacific, U.S. official says, as Trump considers whether to join Israel in striking Iran
text: The B-2, based at Whiteman Air Force Base in Missouri, is the only U.S. aircraft able to carry the 30,000-pound bunker-busting bombs thought to be capable of penetrating Iran’s underground Fordow nuclear enrichment facility. President Donald Trump said Thursday that he would decide whether to strike within two weeks.

alert_body: What do young, single MAGA women want? It’s complicated.
text: What, exactly, is the conservative culture in the age of President Donald Trump’s second coming, and what does it think right-leaning women should want? These were the questions facing the roughly 3,000 young women — mostly ages 16 to 26 — at the Turning Point USA Young Women’s Leadership Summit in Texas.

alert_body: U.S. warplanes carry out strikes on three nuclear sites in Iran, Trump says, calling the attack ‘successful’
text: The strikes targeted nuclear facilities at Fordow, Natanz, and Esfahan, President Donald Trump said on social media Saturday evening. “A full payload of BOMBS was dropped on the primary site, Fordow. All planes are safely on their way home,” he said.

alert_body: President Donald Trump addresses the nation on U.S. strikes on Iranian nuclear sites. Watch our live coverage.
text: Trump announced the targeted strikes on three nuclear facilities in Iran on social media earlier Saturday evening.

alert_body: Any retaliation from Iran would be “met with force far greater than what was witnessed tonight,” Trump says on social media
text: President Donald Trump’s warning followed the United States’ sweeping strikes on Iranian nuclear facilities that marked a major escalation for his administration and tethers the U.S. directly to a conflict with no clear outcome or end in sight.

alert_body: Iranian nuclear sites sustained ‘severe damage’ in U.S. strike, Pentagon says, asserting mission was not about regime change
text: Gen. Dan Caine, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said in a news conference Sunday that the Fordow, Natanz and Isfahan nuclear facilities “sustained extremely severe damage” but that it was too early to tell the scale of destruction. “This mission was not, has not been about regime change” but rather about addressing the threats posed by Iran’s nuclear program, Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth said.

alert_body: Crossword and a coffee: Solve the Sunday puzzle now
text: Crossword and a coffee: Solve the Sunday puzzle now

alert_body: Phoenix Suns agree to trade Kevin Durant to Houston Rockets for package of players and draft picks
text: Durant, a 15-time all-star, will play for the fifth NBA franchise of his 17-year career as a result of the trade, which had been rumored for months after the Suns’ failure to make the playoffs in a disappointing season and will become official next week. The two-time Finals MVP joins a young Rockets team that won 52 games and earned the second seed in the Western Conference in 2024-25 before falling to the Golden State Warriors in the first round.

alert_body: How Trump and his inner circle threw Iran and the rest of the world off guard before the U.S. struck key nuclear sites
text: Within a small circle of White House and administration officials, it was clear that even when President Donald Trump said he might not decide for “two weeks," an attack on Iran’s nuclear facilities was imminent, and the ruse was already underway.

alert_body: Bees are in trouble in the U.S., and a key to unlocking their secrets could disappear
text: Native bees have been declining for years, and commercial honeybee keepers reported one of their biggest colony losses this year. Now the Trump administration plans to defund the federal government’s premier bee research lab, in Laurel, Md., putting its future in peril.

alert_body: Oklahoma City Thunder wins NBA championship, defeating Indiana Pacers in seven games to cap impressive title run
text: The Thunder, led by NBA MVP Shai Gilgeous-Alexander, won a league-best 68 games during the regular season and remained the most complete team during the playoffs. This is the franchise’s first championship since it relocated from Seattle in 2008.

alert_body: What satellite images reveal about damage to Iran’s nuclear sites
text: The images provide the first glimpses of the aftermath of U.S. strikes on three sites said to be central to Iran’s nuclear program, revealing severe damage at aboveground facilities as well as the entry points left by bombs that burrowed deep underground to target some of the program’s most protected operations.

alert_body: A pay raise in today’s On the Record
text: Answer now to earn your Monday points.

alert_body: Harvard flouted the rules. Now, it’s getting a hard lesson, Secretary of Homeland Security Kristi L. Noem writes in an op-ed.
text: Hosting foreign students is a privilege that comes with obligations, Noem writes.

alert_body: ‘You have 12 hours to escape’: An Israeli warning to a top Iranian general reveals a covert campaign to destabilize Tehran
text: An audio recording of a June 13 phone call obtained by The Washington Post offers a window into the stealth campaign by Israeli intelligence to threaten and divide Iranian military and government officials.

alert_body: An extreme heat warning covers the D.C. area today and tomorrow, with near-record highs expected. Here’s what to know.
text: Temperatures are expected to reach the upper 90s to low 100s both afternoons and perhaps on Wednesday. When high humidity is factored in, it will feel as hot as near 110, and the National Weather Service has warned of risks of heat-related illnesses.

alert_body: Explosions reported near U.S. military base in Qatar after Iran vows to retaliate for Trump’s strike on its nuclear sites
text: The development coincided with a warning from the U.S. Embassy in Qatar for American citizens there to shelter in place. Qatar also closed its airspace and suspended flights as a “precautionary measure” while the Middle East braces for a potential expansion of the fighting between Israel and Iran.

alert_body: Carolyn Hax: Friend cuts ties after being called on hurtful remark
text: Carolyn Hax: Friend cuts ties after being called on hurtful remark

alert_body: See images of faraway galaxies and nearby asteroids from the new Vera Rubin telescope and world’s largest digital camera
text: The observatory, named for a pioneering American astronomer, will soon embark on a 10-year “deep and wide” survey of the entire sky in the Southern Hemisphere, promising to see more galaxies than ever seen before. The telescope features a 3,200-megapixel camera. See some of its first images here.

alert_body: Supreme Court for now allows Trump to deport migrants to ‘third countries’
text: The six conservative justices cleared the way for the Trump administration to deport citizens of other countries to a third nation, temporarily blocking a decision by a lower court judge who said migrants must have a “meaningful opportunity” to contest their removal. The case is one of several testing the Trump administration’s aggressive efforts to ramp up deportations, in this case to conflict-ridden South Sudan.

alert_body: Trump claims Iran and Israel have agreed to a ceasefire and an imminent end to their war
text: In his announcement on social media, President Donald Trump congratulated both countries, saying the conflict “could have gone on for years, and destroyed the entire Middle East.” There was no immediate corroborating announcement from either the Israeli or Iranian governments.

alert_body: Netanyahu decided on Iran war last year, then sought to recruit Trump
text: The Israeli prime minister issued a general order in the fall to prepare for a strike, current and former officials say. Israel also tried to sway the U.S. with intelligence about Iran’s nuclear plans, but American analysts did not conclude Iranian leaders had decided to build a bomb.

alert_body: Israel agrees to Trump’s proposed ceasefire with Iran
text: Israel said it achieved its military goals in Iran and thanked President Donald Trump and the U.S. “for their participation in removing the Iranian nuclear threat.”

alert_body: Trump accuses Israel and Iran of violating ceasefire hours after its start
text: As Israel and Iran traded accusations, President Donald Trump said the two countries need to “calm down. Ridiculous.” Trump had announced the ceasefire deal on Monday as an end to what he said should be called the “12-day war.”

text: President Donald Trump and top aides have claimed that U.S. airstrikes obliterated Iran's nuclear program, but people familiar with an initial report by the Defense Intelligence Agency say that core components of Tehran's enrichment program remain intact.

alert_body: We texted 1,000 Americans about Trump’s Iran strikes. Here’s what they said.
text: A Washington Post flash poll finds the airstrikes remain unpopular, but Republican support surged after President Donald Trump ordered the strikes.

alert_body: Zohran Mamdani leads Andrew M. Cuomo on 1st round of counting in New York Democratic mayoral primary
text: Mamdani, who would be New York’s first Muslim mayor, didn’t break the 50 percent mark in the first round of counting, the Associated Press reported. But it was still a good performance for the 33-year-old democratic socialist state assemblyman, a relative newcomer who was facing off with a former governor with copious campaign cash and prominent endorsements. Under the city’s ranked choice system, officials will now drop the candidate who finished last and continue counting votes until a candidate bests 50 percent.

alert_body: Cuomo concedes to Mamdani in New York City’s Democratic mayoral primary
text: “Tonight was not our night,” the former governor told supporters. He said of Mamdani: “Tonight is his night. He deserved it. He won.” Mamdani, a democratic socialist, is now poised for a major upset in the Democratic race after jumping out to a lead after the first round of ballots were tallied Tuesday. Final results in the ranked-choice voting primary are expected to come next week. The Democratic nominee is expected to begin as a favorite in the general election in a heavily blue city.

alert_body: How much would you save or lose with Trump’s ‘big’ tax bill? Try our calculator to find out.
text: President Donald Trump and Republicans in Congress are on the cusp of passing legislation to extend tax cuts and reduce spending on safety net programs. See how the bill would affect your finances — and those of other Americans — using our tool.

alert_body: RFK Jr.’s new vaccine panel to review childhood immunization schedule, a move that could change how and when kids receive shots
text: The newly formed vaccine advisory committee handpicked by Health and Human Services Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. announced it would examine the cumulative effect of the childhood vaccine schedule and reevaluate hepatitis B immunization recommendations. Kennedy, who founded an anti-vaccine group, has long called for an investigation into the number of shots children receive.

alert_body: Trump DOJ sues 15 federal judges in Maryland over deportation order. Legal experts call it an unprecedented attack on judiciary.
text: Government lawyers say they’re aiming to preserve President Donald Trump’s constitutional authority over immigration.

alert_body: Dept. of Housing and Urban Development to move from D.C., displacing National Science Foundation in nearby Alexandria, Virginia
text: It will be the first major federal agency to relocate its headquarters outside of Washington, part of a larger plan to reorganize the federal government's real estate footprint. About 2,700 HUD workers would make the move, pushing out about 1,800 employees at the NSF, which has faced massive spending cuts under the Trump administration.

alert_body: Trump administration plans to limit intelligence sharing with Congress after leaks undermined president’s claims about Iran strikes
text: Details of an early intelligence assessment leaked to the press this week undermined President Donald Trump’s claim that U.S. strikes “obliterated” Iranian nuclear facilities.

alert_body: Dallas Mavericks select Duke forward Cooper Flagg with No. 1 pick in NBA draft
text: Flagg, an 18-year-old from Maine, is widely considered the best American prospect to enter the league in more than a decade. He immediately becomes the face of a Mavericks franchise that traded superstar Luka Doncic to the Los Angeles Lakers in February.

alert_body: Intelligence leak. Unprecedented lawsuit. Kids’ vaccines. Zohran Mamdani. Aging population. Heat dome. Bear escape. Catch up now.

alert_body: Immigration is driving population growth in a graying America, census data shows. See how your county’s population has changed.
text: Children still outnumber older adults, but the gap is narrowing as baby boomers age, the data found. A historic rise in immigration, particularly among Hispanics and Asians, has counteracted some of the decline in births.

text: Answer now to earn your Thursday points.

alert_body: Supreme Court paves way for states to defund Planned Parenthood, ruling Medicaid patients cannot sue for non-abortion care
text: The case addressed whether a provision of the federal Medicaid Act allows individuals to sue for access to their provider of choice. It was brought by a woman who wants South Carolina to resume Medicaid funding to Planned Parenthood for non-abortion health care.

alert_body: In closing arguments of Sean Combs trial, prosecutors say he ‘used power, violence and fear to get what he wanted.’ Follow live.
text: The jury in Sean “Diddy” Combs’s sex-trafficking case has heard more than six weeks of testimony from 34 witnesses. Now, the prosecution and defense will make their final pitches to the jurors deciding Combs’s fate.

alert_body: Our analysis of the NBA draft’s winners and losers: Mavericks made the easy choice with Cooper Flagg, but Pelicans took risks
text: Dallas selected the Duke star with the No. 1 pick in the draft Wednesday night, before other teams followed more questionable paths. NBA writer Ben Golliver analyzes all of the biggest decisions.

alert_body: Carolyn Hax: Brother’s two broken engagements have family balking at his third
text: Carolyn Hax: Brother’s two broken engagements have family balking at his third

alert_body: RFK Jr. appointees vote to effectively remove a flu shot preservative, advancing a priority of anti-vaccine activists
text: The Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices — overhauled by Health and Human Services Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. — voted Thursday to stop recommending flu shots containing the preservative thimerosal, which research has shown is safe. Most flu shots are thimerosal-free, but public health experts said the move could make shots more expensive and harder to receive. Many also expressed concern that anti-vaccine rhetoric is becoming official government guidance.

alert_body: Bill Moyers dies at 91. The acclaimed journalist won renown for bringing discussion of ideas — both timely and timeless — to TV.
text: He was White House press secretary under Lyndon B. Johnson and Newsday publisher before beginning a television career that would bring him more than 30 Emmy Awards, including one for lifetime achievement. He was mainly associated with PBS, and although he frequently explored societal ills, he was happier speaking with poets and philosophers than he was with pollsters or politicians.

alert_body: Supreme Court. DOGE and guns. Young Democrats. Iran strikes. Diddy trial. Another heat wave. Fireball video. Catch up now.
text: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

alert_body: Supreme Court is ruling on major remaining cases, including nationwide injunctions and birthright citizenship. Follow our coverage.
text: The justices have left some of the most important and contentious cases until the end. They are slated to release six opinions, including decisions that will deal with injunctions regarding President Donald Trump’s ban on birthright citizenship, whether parents can opt their children out of school lessons involving LGBTQ books, and a Texas law that requires age verification to view online porn.

alert_body: DOGE enters ATF with mandate to slash gun regulations as Trump administration pushes to drastically reduce number of inspectors
text: The U.S. DOGE Service is working with the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives general counsel to cut more than 50 regulations. Gun-control advocates fear the changes will more easily allow potentially dangerous people to obtain weapons with little recourse.

alert_body: Supreme Court upholds Affordable Care Act’s preventive-care mandate
text: The justices ruled against a Christian-owned business and individuals who objected to being forced to offer medications intended to prevent the spread of HIV among at-risk populations. The challengers argued that the panel that determined what care must be covered was improperly appointed.

alert_body: Supreme Court limits nationwide orders blocking Trump’s birthright citizenship ban
text: The 6-3 ruling will impact decisions by lower-court judges to block President Donald Trump’s ban on birthright citizenship and probably other Trump administration initiatives. The president asked the justices to scale back those injunctions, which halted his policies nationwide while legal challenges to them were pending.

alert_body: Supreme Court upholds law requiring age checks for porn sites
text: More than 20 states require age verification to protect young people from accessing lewd online content. The justices rejected arguments from the porn industry that the Texas law violates the First Amendment rights of adults by requiring them to share identifying information that could be sold, misused or hacked.

alert_body: Supreme Court sides with religious parents seeking to opt out of lessons with LGBTQ storybooks
text: The 6-3 decision backed a group of parents seeking to withdraw their children from public school lessons featuring gay and transgender characters, a case that mixed parental rights and religious freedom.

alert_body: Carolyn Hax chat: My teen feels pressured by her boyfriend’s pushy mom
text: Carolyn Hax chat: My teen feels pressured by her boyfriend’s pushy mom

alert_body: Trump officials plan to resettle 1,000 Afrikaners by end of September, document shows
text: The plan to ramp up the arrival of White South Africans comes as officials simultaneously move to block refugees from other countries. A federal judge had ordered the Trump administration to admit certain refugees, but a court record shows the administration is now moving to halt their entry.

alert_body: University of Virginia President James E. Ryan tells board he’ll resign amid Justice Department pressure against DEI initiatives
text: A person familiar with the situation said Justice Department officials had previously indicated to Ryan that they’d like him to step down.

alert_body: Trump calls off trade talks with Canada and threatens tariffs on Canadian goods, saying he objects to new digital services tax
text: The Canadian tax on big tech companies is set to take effect Monday. Trump said he would announce tariff rates for goods from Canada within seven days.

alert_body: Iran nearly succeeded in orchestrating an assassination of former secretary of state Mike Pompeo in Europe in 2022, book reveals
text: The forthcoming book also reveals that Donald Trump and his campaign were told by intelligence officials last September that Iran had recruited hit men who remained active on U.S. soil at the time. Security threats to Trump and his aides, including from Iran, dramatically changed their practices and worldview on the campaign trail, according to an account from the book, obtained by The Washington Post. The book, “2024: How Trump Retook the White House and the Democrats Lost America,” was written by current and former Washington Post reporters Josh Dawsey, Tyler Pager and Isaac Arnsdorf.

alert_body: S&P 500 squeaks out record high after Trump ends trade talks with Canada
text: The U.S. stock market has been a roller coaster this year, rising to record levels in February and then tumbling in April after President Donald Trump announced tariffs on all imported goods. Since then, easing trade tensions with China and other nations, as well a U.S. pullback from the steepest levies, helped push shares higher.

alert_body: U.S. DOGE Service loses control of process for awarding billions in federal funds, in latest sign of its declining influence
text:
Federal officials were instructed Thursday to stop routing the grant-making process through DOGE, the fate of which has remained uncertain since Elon Musk departed the government.
The move follows fears that months of DOGE-linked delays would lead to the impoundment of federal funds, according to emails obtained by The Post and two people familiar with the situation, both of whom spoke on the condition of anonymity to describe a sensitive situation.

alert_body: The 50 best airports in America, ranked
text: To build our best airports list, The Washington Post analyzed feedback from more than 2,300 readers and collected data on 450-plus U.S. locations to build the definitive ranking. Turns out, bigger isn’t better.

alert_body: This songwriter shaped today’s country music with a record-breaking 83 No. 1 hits. You’ve never heard of him.
text: Ashley Gorley spent years trying to crack the code behind a hit song. It paid off.

alert_body: Senate narrowly votes to begin debate on Trump’s sweeping tax and immigration bill, amid Republican divisions
text: By a 51-49 margin, Senate Republicans voted late Saturday night to start debate on the massive package. Two Republican senators joined all Democrats in voting against advancing the bill in a roll call that stayed open for hours as GOP leaders navigated internal divisions. Now, the Senate will kick off debating the measure and holding votes on amendments, a process that could drag into next week.

alert_body: Fairfax County Supervisor James R. Walkinshaw wins Democratic nomination to replace late Rep. Gerry Connolly (D-Virginia)
text: The winner will face off against GOP nominee Stewart Whitson in the deep-blue 11th Congressional District. The seat had opened up for the first time since 2008 when Connolly died after being diagnosed with cancer.

text: Crossword and a coffee: Solve the Sunday puzzle now

alert_body: Star witness against Kilmar Abrego García was due to be deported. Now he’s being freed.
text: The Trump administration has agreed to release three-time felon Jose Ramon Hernandez Reyes from prison in exchange for his cooperation in the federal prosecution of Abrego, according to a review of court records and official testimony. Abrego was illegally deported to a notorious megaprison in El Salvador in March and was brought back to the United States earlier this month to face migrant smuggling charges.

alert_body: Still need to finish this weekend’s On the Record? We’ve got you.
text: Play now to finish out your score for the week.

alert_body: Intercepted call captures Iranian officials saying U.S. attack on nuclear sites was less devastating than they expected
text: U.S. intelligence obtained private communication among Iranian officials, offering a different assessment than the one conveyed by President Donald Trump, who has said the operation “completely and totally obliterated” Iran’s nuclear program. The Trump administration is downplaying the call’s significance.

alert_body: Sen. Thom Tillis (R-North Carolina) won’t seek reelection after Trump threatened him with primary challenge for opposing tax bill
text: Tillis was one of two Republican senators who voted Saturday night against beginning debate on the tax and spending bill that is President Donald Trump’s top legislative priority.

alert_body: After Pride was banned, Hungarians wanted to resist but understood the risk. Here’s how they defied Prime Minister Viktor Orban.
text: Post journalists followed Kristof Steiner, an organizer of Budapest Pride, as he and other members of Hungary’s LGBTQ+ community countered a law prohibiting the event.

alert_body: Priscilla Chan and Mark Zuckerberg stopped funding social causes. 400 kids lost their school.
text: The closure of a school Chan opened in 2016 to help struggling families shows the risks for communities reliant on wealthy private donors.

alert_body: Two firefighters killed in ‘ambush’ while responding to blaze in Idaho, authorities say
text: The firefighters were attacked Sunday afternoon while responding to a brush fire in a hiking area near Coeur d’Alene, in northern Idaho, according to local authorities, who said the scene remains active and a suspect has not been apprehended. The local fire chief called it an ‘ambush-style attack’ and said multiple firefighters were transported to the hospital.

alert_body: Supreme Court takes up major campaign finance case for next term, examining limits on political party spending
text: The justices will hear a Republican challenge to restrictions on the amount of money that political parties can spend in coordination with individual candidates. The national Republican senatorial and congressional committees say the limits conflict with the free speech rights guaranteed by the First Amendment.

text: A review of satellite imagery and videos revealed damage that pointed to multiple strikes, experts said, with structures nearly 2,000 feet apart in ruins. At least four civilians were killed, two of them children, according to online death notices and witness interviews.

alert_body: These twins were college divers. Then new NCAA rules cost them their spots.

Landmark changes to the college sports economy — stemming from a multibillion-dollar legal settlement last month that permits colleges to directly pay athletes for the first time — left their futures in jeopardy.

alert_body: Nationals fire manager Dave Martinez, GM Mike Rizzo amid dismal season for rebuilding club
text: The Nationals on Sunday ended one of the longest partnerships in baseball, which included a World Series title in 2019 — the first in franchise history — and the second-worst record in baseball in the six years that followed. Martinez had spent eight years with the organization, while Rizzo was promoted to general manager in 2009. Mike DeBartolo will take over as interim GM; an interim manager will be announced Monday, the team said.

alert_body: Why aren’t Italians as obese as Americans? It’s not really what they eat, our food policy columnist writes.
text: Multicourse meals, charcuterie, ravioli, pizza, gelato: On its face, this doesn’t seem like a recipe for avoiding weight gain. But there’s a much lower obesity rate in Italy than in the U.S. Here’s why.

alert_body: Texas Hill Country is no stranger to flash floods. Why were so many caught off guard?
text: Even in the most flood-prone region in the country, the disaster during Fourth of July weekend exposed gaps in the ability to warn people about the coming deluge. Many people failed to receive or respond to flood warnings at riverside campsites and cabins that were known to be in the floodplain. And Kerr County itself didn’t send a push alert amid continued rains on Sunday.

alert_body: Australian woman found guilty in ‘mushroom murder case’
text: Erin Patterson, a 50-year-old mother of two, was found guilty of murdering three relatives and attempting to murder a fourth by feeding them a lunch laced with death cap mushrooms at her home outside Melbourne in 2023. The “mushroom murder case,” as it was known in Australia, transfixed the country, and the verdict brings to a close a dramatic two-month trial.

Cairo, who previously served as Martinez's bench coach, will now guide a Nationals team that includes outfielder James Wood and lefty MacKenzie Gore, two young talents who were named all-stars Sunday. The changes in Washington come amid a long rebuild for the franchise, which has shed its stars in the years since its 2019 World Series triumph.

alert_body: Veterans Affairs reverses course on large-scale job reductions after promising to cut 83,000 roles
text:
The agency says it will have reduced the number of staff by the end of fiscal 2025 by approximately 30,000 through hiring freezes, retirements and attrition.

Further cuts to the agency would have brought deep political risks for President Donald Trump, who remains popular with military veterans and has promised to not do anything that would affect their benefits or care.

text: Andreessen co-founded one of Silicon Valley’s most prominent venture capital firms, Andreessen Horowitz, which embraced Donald Trump’s candidacy last year. While Elon Musk was the most visible tech mogul in Trump’s orbit until he split with the president, Andreessen has quietly helped shape the administration’s hiring and policy decisions.

alert_body: He knows he was adopted from South Korea. When he started digging into his past, red flags emerged.
text: For years, Aaron Grzegorczyk thought his birth mother had left him at a South Korean clinic in 1988. A recent report found the country had allowed a “profit-driven” adoption “industry” to flourish for decades, leaving Grzegorczyk wondering whether he’s yet another victim.

alert_body: ICE memo outlines plan to deport migrants to countries where they are not citizens
text: Federal immigration officers may deport immigrants with as little as six hours’ notice to countries other than their own even if officials have not provided any assurances that the new arrivals will be safe from persecution or torture, a top official said in a memo this week. The dramatic shift in policy could result in thousands of people being sent to places where they lack family ties or even a common language.

alert_body: Six less-expensive beach vacations in the U.S., from Georgia to California

alert_body: National Park Service tells its gift shops to remove anything that ‘disparages Americans’
text: Park staff were ordered to report any retail items containing content that “inappropriately disparages Americans past or living” or that includes “matters unrelated to the beauty, abundance or grandeur” of a natural feature in its description. The move is part of the administration’s wider campaign to scrub federal institutions of “corrosive ideology” recognizing historical racism and sexism.

alert_body: Jannik Sinner wins first Wimbledon championship and fourth Grand Slam title, denying Carlos Alcaraz a third straight victory there
text: It was the first appearance in the Wimbledon final for Sinner, the 23-year-old Italian who avenged his loss to Alcaraz at last month's French Open. He and Alcaraz, a 22-year-old from Spain, have combined to win the last seven men’s Grand Slam titles.

alert_body: A clinic blames its closing on Trump’s Medicaid cuts. Some patients don’t buy it.
text: A clinic in rural Nebraska has become a political flash point after tying its pending closure to Trump’s law cutting Medicaid. Residents of Curtis — a one-stoplight town in deep-red farm country — are sorry to lose the clinic but skeptical of the rationale.

alert_body: After franchise upheaval, Washington Nationals select infielder Eli Willits with the No. 1 pick in the MLB draft
text: The selection of Willits, a 17-year-old high school shortstop from Oklahoma, came just one week after Washington fired its longtime general manager, Mike Rizzo. Mike DeBartolo has taken the helm as interim GM of the Nationals, who also fired manager Dave Martinez. The Nationals previously used No. 1 picks on Bryce Harper and Stephen Strasburg, setting a high bar for their choice this year.

alert_body: How the Trump assassination attempt supercharged beliefs in a divine right of MAGA
text: President Donald Trump and many of his followers have described the rally shooting on July 13, 2024, as a mass spiritual awakening, promoting the belief that Trump enacts God’s will.

text:
Interviews with nearly two dozen counselors, emergency officials, parents and experts reveal that as Camp Mystic Executive Director Dick Eastland conferred with family members and other employees about how to respond to the alert, the camp descended into chaos as the river rose to record levels.

Water was at least four feet high around many of the cabins, a Washington Post analysis found.

Lawyers say the policy will apply to millions of immigrants who crossed the U.S.-Mexico border over the past few decades, including under former president Joe Biden.

text: The episode in April, which has not been reported previously, was sparked by claims that a team leader with Elon Musk’s cost-cutting organization had summoned law enforcement to remove a subordinate from the Pentagon installation, people familiar with the matter said. Hegseth, these people said, deemed it an unacceptable overreach.

alert_body: Expelled D.C. Council member Trayon White Sr. (D) projected to win special election for his former Ward 8 seat
text: White, who was expelled in February after his arrest and indictment on a federal bribery charge, will return to the council for a term that ends in January 2029. He has pleaded not guilty to the charge.

alert_body: Adelita Grijalva wins Democratic nomination for U.S. House in Arizona special election
text: Grijalva won a contested primary in a safely Democratic district, defeating Gen Z content creator Deja Foxx and others. The contest underlined intraparty tensions over age, experience and dynastic politics. Grijalva will be a heavy favorite in the special election to succeed her father, liberal stalwart Raúl Grijalva, who represented the district until his death in March.

alert_body: Trump administration adds level of approval to wind and solar projects, threatening to slow them down as tax credit deadline looms
text: The Interior Department announced a new level of “enhanced oversight” for renewable energy projects, which will now require approval by the secretary’s office. The move introduces a hurdle to projects that were racing to begin construction before a July 2026 deadline to qualify for tax credits, which were gutted by President Donald Trump’s One Big Beautiful Bill.

alert_body: Brazil’s former president Jair Bolsonaro is charged with leading a coup. His son is pushing Trump to sanction a judge in his trial.

alert_body: The Texas flooding was the deadliest tragedy for children in decades. Here’s who was lost.
text: They adored animals and sports. They loved to draw and read. Their giggles were contagious, their hugs spontaneous. Amid the grief, relatives have sought to celebrate what made the children special — and hinted at the young adults they might have one day become.

alert_body: CBS cancels Stephen Colbert’s ‘Late Show’ in what the network says was a financial decision
text: The late-night talk show will end in May 2026. The announcement came days after Colbert spoke out against the $16 million paid by Paramount, the parent company of CBS News, to settle a lawsuit filed by Donald Trump during last year’s presidential campaign.

alert_body: House passes $9 billion in spending cuts, sending package to Trump’s desk
text: The House slashed funding for foreign aid and the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, which funds PBS and NPR. The Senate earlier this week passed the cuts, known as rescissions, meaning the bill will soon become law. The House vote was significantly delayed because of the political pressure facing Republicans around the release of government files related to convicted sex-offender Jeffrey Epstein.

text: Stephen Colbert announced at the Thursday evening taping of “The Late Show with Stephen Colbert” that he’d found out, only the night before, that his show would be canceled in May 2026 and that no one would be replacing him.

alert_body: Trump’s antisemitism task force takes aim at other conservative complaints about colleges
text: The administration created the Joint Task Force on Anti-Semitism to counter what it describes as widespread failure by universities to protect Jewish students. In reality, many of its unprecedented demands and punishments have nothing to do with antisemitism and instead relate to a conservative campaign to root out diversity, equity and inclusion initiatives and a liberal worldview on college campuses.

alert_body: Trump administration swaps more than 250 Venezuelans sent to notorious Salvadoran prison for Americans held by Caracas
text: The State Department coordinated the exchange involving Venezuelans who were held at the high-security CECOT “counterterrorism” prison. The Americans are a mix of U.S. citizens and permanent residents who were imprisoned by the government of President Nicolás Maduro.

alert_body: What causes obesity? A major new study is upending common wisdom.
text: The study found that people living in developed countries expend about the same number of calories most days as hunter-gatherers and anyone living in less-industrialized nations, suggesting that inactivity is not the main cause of obesity.

alert_body: Justice Department asks a federal court to release Epstein grand jury testimony
text: Trump administration officials have asked a federal court to unseal more grand jury testimony in the sex-trafficking case against former financier Jeffrey Epstein. The request comes as political outcry intensifies over the administration’s unfulfilled promise to release more details on the matter.

alert_body: EPA eliminates its scientific research arm, cementing plans to cut nearly a quarter of its entire staff
text: The Environmental Protection Agency said it would dismantle the Office of Research and Development, which conducts independent research on environmental hazards. Agency officials said the EPA has now cut 23 percent of its overall staff through layoffs, separations and retirements, saving taxpayers more than $748 million.

text: Former officer Brett Hankison faced up to life in prison. His case has been closely watched by civil rights activists who have pressed for police accountability in Taylor’s death, which helped spark mass social justice protests in 2020. In an unusual court filing last week, the Justice Department suggested Hankison shouldn't have faced federal charges and recommended that he be sentenced to a day in jail.

alert_body: Coke says cane sugar soda is coming to the U.S., a move hailed by Trump. There’s little evidence it’s healthier, studies show.
text: President Donald Trump said last week that he had spoken to Coca-Cola about making its product in the United States with cane sugar, as it does in Mexico. The company announced Tuesday it would roll out a U.S. version as an option this fall. But studies do not show it has substantial benefits over Coke with high-fructose corn syrup.

alert_body: NPR editor in chief says she's stepping down days after Congress cut all federal funding for public broadcasting
text: News veteran Edith Chapin says she is leaving her post at National Public Radio. NPR CEO Katherine Maher said in an email that Chapin’s decision came two weeks ago ahead of the Senate’s vote to pass President Donald Trump’s rescission bill, which stripped the Corporation for Public Broadcasting of $1.1 billion for NPR, PBS and member stations over the next two years.

alert_body: Ozzy Osbourne dies at 76. The Black Sabbath frontman helped pioneer heavy metal’s thunderous, earsplitting sound.
text: Playful and flamboyant, with an exuberant personality that belied the foreboding music he recorded with Black Sabbath in the 1970s, Osbourne was a dominant figure in heavy metal for more than four decades, known as much for his manic performance style as his distinctive nasal yawp.

alert_body: Judges vote to oust former Trump lawyer Alina Habba as New Jersey’s interim U.S. attorney
text: New Jersey’s federal judges declined Tuesday to appoint Habba, President Donald Trump’s pick for the state’s top federal prosecutor, to continue serving in that role, delivering a resounding rebuke to one of his most polarizing Justice Department appointees. The state’s U.S. district court judges made the announcement in a brief order that did not offer any explanation for their decision.

alert_body: U.N.’s highest court rules that countries have a duty to limit greenhouse gases, potentially bolstering climate lawsuits worldwide
text: The International Court of Justice ruling said countries are obliged to cut planet-warming pollution and any breach represents an “internationally wrongful act.” While non-binding, the decision could boost cases across the globe and ultimately lead to reparations for vulnerable countries damaged by global warming.

text: Bryan Kohberger pleaded guilty earlier this month as part of a plea deal that eliminated the possibility of the death penalty. The high-profile case disrupted a quiet Idaho town, inspired several books and became a subject of speculation by true-crime fans.

alert_body: Disclosures by Hegseth’s Signal account derived from email classified ‘SECRET,’ IG is told, contradicting Trump officials' claims
text: The Pentagon’s independent watchdog has received evidence that messages from the defense secretary's Signal account previewing a U.S. bombing campaign in Yemen derived from a classified email labeled “SECRET/NOFORN,” people familiar with the matter said, contradicting repeated claims by the Trump administration that no classified information was divulged in unclassified group chats.

alert_body: Justice Department's request to release Epstein transcripts is denied by Florida judge
text:
A federal judge in Florida has denied the Justice Department’s request to unseal grand jury transcripts from the investigation of deceased financier Jeffrey Epstein in that state.
The department — facing increasing pressure from President Donald Trump’s political base — petitioned the court last week to release those typically closely held records of witness testimony.

alert_body: Supreme Court allows Trump to remove Democrats from agency that regulates safety of everyday consumer products
text: The Trump administration had asked the justices to allow the president to remove three of the five members of the Consumer Product Safety Commission, which evaluates products such as strollers and bicycles and coordinates recalls.

alert_body: He got away with murder for 23 years. Video shows his response as police confront him.
text: Eugene Gligor struggled to collect himself after learning his DNA was at the scene of a 2001 murder in Chevy Chase, Maryland. What came next wasn’t a confession. But it wasn’t exactly a denial.

alert_body: Columbia University and Trump administration strike a deal over federal funding
text: White House officials have cast Columbia University as the epicenter of antisemitism. This deal would resolve a dispute over federal funding.

alert_body: With GOP support, House Oversight subcommittee takes step to subpoena Justice Department for Epstein files
text: Three Republicans joined with Democrats to advance language to force the full release of the Epstein files after an amendment was introduced by Rep. Summer Lee (D-Pennsylvania). Republican lawmakers have been feeling the same pressure as President Donald Trump to respond to anger from his base about the Justice Department's recent decision not to release the files.

alert_body: ICE moves to shackle some 180,000 immigrants with GPS ankle monitors, a sharp increase in round-the-clock monitoring
text: In an internal ICE document reviewed by The Washington Post, U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement ordered staff to place ankle monitors on all people enrolled in the agency’s Alternatives to Detention program “whenever possible.” Currently, just 24,000 of these individuals wear ankle monitors.

alert_body: Hulk Hogan dies at 71. The pro wrestling star’s tabloid-centric private life became a legal battleground over the First Amendment.
text: Florida wrestler Terry Bollea, who shot to stardom as Hulk Hogan, reigned supreme for a generation of professional wrestling fans. Decades after his heyday in the ring, Bollea became a fixture in the courtroom after suing the owners of a popular gossip website that showed portions of a sex tape featuring Bollea and the wife of a friend.

alert_body: Carolyn Hax: Husband is losing his ability to manage small frustrations
text: Carolyn Hax: Husband is losing his ability to manage small frustrations

alert_body: Wisconsin Gov. Tony Evers (D) announces he won’t seek a third term in his swing state
text: The decision is expected to set off a scramble as other Democrats weigh running to replace Evers. He defeated Gov. Scott Walker (R) in 2018, ending Republicans’ eight-year run of complete control of state government.

alert_body: Amy Sherald, who painted Michelle Obama portrait, cancels Smithsonian show over alleged ‘censorship’ of a transgender-themed work
text: The Smithsonian denied that it planned to censor the show at the National Portrait Gallery, whose leader recently resigned after President Donald Trump claimed he fired her.

alert_body: Mass starvation is stalking Gaza as Israel restricts aid and deaths from hunger rise
text: Testimonies from doctors, relief workers and Gazans make it clear that a worst-case scenario is unfolding: Nearly 1 in 3 people are going multiple days without eating, according to the United Nations, and hospitals are reporting rising deaths.

alert_body: USDA will relocate most of its D.C.-based workforce and close several key facilities
text: The agency will move about 2,600 employees to five other locations in the country and shutter some facilities in the capital region. The closures will include the Henry A. Wallace Beltsville Agricultural Research Center, a 6,500-acre operation that dates back 115 years and is one of the world’s largest facilities of its kind.

alert_body: France will recognize a Palestinian state, Macron says, calling for an urgent end to the war in Gaza
text: In a statement, French President Emmanuel Macron said he would recognize Palestine at the U.N. General Assembly in September. “The urgent need today is to end the war in Gaza and to rescue the civilian population,” he said, adding that there is no other way to build lasting security in the Middle East.

alert_body: Trump administration sues New York City for using sanctuary city policies to impede immigration crackdown efforts
text:
The legal action comes days after an off-duty Customs and Border Protection officer was shot during an ambush robbery attempt in an upper Manhattan park, allegedly by a pair of undocumented immigrants.
The Justice Department says in its filing that the nation’s largest city has been flouting its obligations to assist in federal immigration enforcement by operating as a sanctuary city for decades.

alert_body: FCC approves $8 billion Paramount-Skydance merger after lengthy review marked by controversy
text: The merger, which drew allegations of political pressure on Paramount-owned CBS News, was approved by a 2-1 vote, with Biden-appointed commissioner Anna M. Gomez voting against the transaction.

alert_body: Trump signs order pushing for more forced hospitalizations of homeless people with mental illness and addiction

text:
The president has already announced frameworks of trade agreements with roughly a dozen of the country’s closest trading partners, including the United Kingdom, the European Union, Japan and South Korea.
But goods from nations with which the U.S. does hundreds of billions of dollars of trade, such as India, Switzerland and South Africa, will see new taxes of up to 39 percent, with India’s rate set to jump to 50 percent in three weeks. Economists say the sweeping new taxes on imports will likely get passed on to U.S. consumers and businesses.

alert_body: Justice Dept. subpoenas N.Y. Attorney General Letitia James about Trump fraud probe
text: One of the subpoenas focused on James’s successful civil fraud case against Donald Trump and his real estate empire, which resulted in a judge ruling in 2024 that Trump and his company needed to pay $450 million in fines, people familiar with the probe said. A second subpoena suggested that the Justice Department is looking into James’s high-profile litigation against the National Rifle Association, which led to court-mandated changes for the group, they said.

alert_body: Smithsonian restores Trump to impeachment display in National Museum of American History exhibit but makes slight changes

alert_body: James Lovell dies at 97. He commanded the troubled Apollo 13 spacecraft and was played by Tom Hanks in a Hollywood film.
text:
In 1970, Lovell shepherded Apollo 13 on its lunar voyage, including a perilous journey back to Earth after an oxygen tank exploded. “Houston, we’ve had a problem,” Lovell told Mission Control as the ordeal transfixed the world.
Apollo 13 became a saga of mythological proportions, especially after the film that starred Tom Hanks as Lovell.

alert_body: Trump will replace IRS Commissioner Billy Long; Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent will run tax agency in the interim
text: Long, a former Republican member of Congress, had little tax policy background. It wasn't clear when a new full-time IRS chief would be named.

alert_body: Texas attorney general files lawsuit to remove fleeing Democrats from office
text: Attorney General Ken Paxton (R) filed a lawsuit to remove 13 of the more than 50 Democrats who left the state to block a GOP effort to redraw the congressional map. The move escalates a tense showdown over redistricting ahead of the midterm elections.

Kennedy Jr. funded a lawsuit against the health agency to force the revival of the task force, raising concerns from vaccine experts about the motivations of a new committee.

alert_body: The GOP is betting Latino Trump voters will keep them in power. That’s no sure thing.

Smith issued an order Thursday that officers may now assist federal immigration enforcement efforts by sharing information about people not in custody, including those encountered at traffic stops. They may also assist by transporting federal immigration agency employees and their detained suspects.

alert_body: Attorney General Pam Bondi orders D.C. mayor to recognize DEA chief as ‘emergency police commissioner’
text: In a signed order, Attorney General Pam Bondi said Terrance Cole, head of the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration, should assume all powers and duties of the chief of police and that the department’s top officers “must receive approval” from him before issuing any directives. Bondi said Cole's appointment would last through President Donald Trump’s emergency declaration in the District.

alert_body: Homeland Security Secretary Kristi L. Noem is living for free in Coast Guard commandant's home in highly unusual arrangement

alert_body: The first hurricane of the season has formed in the Atlantic. Erin could intensify into a major Category 4 storm by Monday.
text: Erin will track close enough to the Caribbean islands to bring heavy rain, possible flooding and dangerous waves this weekend, even as the storm is expected to avoid landfall. The East Coast isn’t out of the woods for next week, with rip currents and rough surf expected. Bermuda may also see bad weather next week.

alert_body: Michigan football receives array of fines and suspensions for sign-stealing operation uncovered during national championship season
text: The NCAA’s announcement Friday marks the conclusion of a nearly two-year process that began when news broke early in the 2023 season that Connor Stalions, then a low-level member of then-coach Jim Harbaugh’s staff, allegedly coordinated an improper in-person scouting and sign-stealing operation against future Michigan opponents.

alert_body: Trump, Witkoff and Rubio land in Anchorage for talks with Russian President Vladimir Putin, with Ukraine peace on the line
text: President Donald Trump, who is joined by special envoy Steve Witkoff and Secretary of State Marco Rubio, has said he will know quickly whether the meeting will be productive and will end it early if warranted.

alert_body: Judge: D.C. police chief remains in command, but Trump can demand help on immigration
text: U.S. District Judge Ana C. Reyes did not issue a ruling but got attorneys for D.C. and the Justice Department to hash out an agreement that preserves local control of the police department. The judge also said Friday that President Donald Trump likely had the legal authority to get help from local police on immigration enforcement.

alert_body: After more than three hours of private talks in Alaska, Trump and Putin prepare to take reporters' questions. Follow our coverage.
text: President Donald Trump and Russian President Vladimir Putin's high-stakes talks Friday held the potential to end the Kremlin’s war in Ukraine and shape the course of security in Europe for a generation. Trump said on his way to Anchorage that he is optimistic that "something’s going to come of it."

alert_body: Trump, Putin signal no concrete agreement on Ukraine, take no questions after breaking off summit early
text: President Donald Trump and Russian President Vladimir Putin emerged sober-faced from their closed-door talks, exchanging niceties but acknowledging that no final deal had been reached to achieve peace in Ukraine. Trump said he would soon be speaking to Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky, along with European leaders, to continue the push for agreement.

alert_body: Gov. Gavin Newsom and other Democrats roll out a new map to counteract a GOP plan to redraw districts in Texas and other states
text: The new California map would add up to five more Democratic House seats, likely wiping out the gains Republicans hope to make in Texas and intensifying a brutal national redistricting fight.

alert_body: Air Canada cancels hundreds of flights as a strike involving some 10,000 flight attendants takes effect
text: The strike means most Air Canada flights will be grounded, including international flights, a union spokesperson said. More than 600 flights have been canceled, with more expected.

alert_body: Zelensky says he will meet with Trump in Washington on Monday to discuss Alaska summit
text: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky made the announcement after a “long and substantive” telephone conversation with President Donald Trump. He said the meeting on Monday would be used to “discuss all of the details regarding ending the killing and the war.”

alert_body: Trump drops Ukraine war ceasefire demand, in a reversal that aligns him with Russia’s Putin, splits with European allies
text: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky, with the backing of European leaders, has previously insisted that a ceasefire must be in place before any negotiations to end the war. Russian President Vladimir Putin has long pushed for negotiations toward a final agreement that would allow fighting to continue in the meantime.

text: It’s happening: People are starting to talk like ChatGPT

alert_body: Third federal judge rejects DOJ’s request to unseal Epstein grand jury transcripts, saying public interest doesn’t outweigh secrecy
text: The Justice Department asked three different federal judges to release transcripts related to the investigation. And U.S. District Judge Richard Berman, who has been overseeing the legal proceedings of the Jeffrey Epstein case in New York, is the third judge to reject the request.

alert_body: Why so few Americans read for pleasure, according to a new study
text: Only 16 percent of Americans age 15 and over read for leisure every day in 2023, according to a study published Wednesday in the journal iScience, compared with 28 percent of Americans in 2003. The new findings from researchers at the University of Florida and University College London come as Americans’ attention spans and print book sales are in decline, and artificial intelligence technology is aiming to summarize knowledge as quickly as possible.

alert_body: Education Department drops long-standing guidance that directed schools to accommodate students who are not fluent in English
text: The move is an acceleration of President Donald Trump’s executive order declaring English the country’s “official language.”

alert_body: State Department fires top press officer for Israeli-Palestinian affairs after internal debates over Middle East policies
text: Shahed Ghoreishi recommended expressing condolences for slain journalists in Gaza and opposing the forced displacement of Palestinians, according to documents reviewed by The Washington Post. U.S. officials said the firing sent a chilling message to State Department employees that communication straying from ardent pro-Israel messaging — even if it’s in line with long-standing U.S. policy — will not be tolerated.

alert_body: Texas House approves election map favored by Trump after Democrats return to state, moving it closer to final passage
text: The Republican-controlled chamber passed the map, which would create five new congressional districts in areas President Donald Trump won by double digits in 2024 and set off a nationwide partisan fight over redistricting. The state Senate is expected to pass it as soon as this week and send it to Gov. Greg Abbott (R) for his signature.

alert_body: Justice Dept. subpoenas sought addresses, doctors’ notes, text messages on care for transgender minors
text: The unusual demand for detailed information about patients suggests the Trump administration wants to launch civil or criminal investigations of medical providers in states where gender transition care for minors remains legal.

alert_body: Ukraine-Russia. ICE in D.C. Voting maps. Transgender patients. Beef prices. Reading slump. Windowless window seats. Catch up now.
text: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

alert_body: U.S and E.U. release details of trade pact that would keep tariffs high on European vehicles and lower semiconductor tariffs
text: A joint statement confirmed that the United States will impose a 15 percent tariff on most European products. The U.S. has now agreed to lower its 25 percent tariff on imported cars to 15 percent for European vehicles once the European Union introduces legislation to eliminate its already-low tariffs on American industrial products.

alert_body: This South American country is the topic of today’s On the Record
text: Answer now to earn your Thursday points.

alert_body: Evangelical leader James Dobson dies at 89. He fueled the rise of the religious right through his group Focus on the Family.
text: Dobson, a child psychologist, built a national following with his talk radio empire and nonprofit, Focus on the Family. He attracted an estimated 7 million weekly listeners and marshaled support for President Ronald Reagan’s election in 1980.

alert_body: Trump says he will patrol D.C. streets tonight alongside law enforcement officials
text: “I’m going to be going out tonight with the police and with the military," President Donald Trump said in an interview aired with talk show host Todd Starnes.

alert_body: Carolyn Hax: Physical 5-year-old roughhouses right through parental warnings
text: Carolyn Hax: Physical 5-year-old roughhouses right through parental warnings

alert_body: Appeals court voids $500 million fine in N.Y. civil case against Trump but upholds fraud finding
text: In February, New York Attorney General Letitia James won a history-making civil case against President Donald Trump, his company, two of his children and two former executives when a state court judge determined that they collectively committed a long-running fraud. On Thursday, the state appeals court called the nearly $500 million fine “excessive.”

alert_body: A Justice Department employee threw a sub at a federal agent and was fired. Now ‘Sandwich Guy’ is a resistance icon.
text: Sandwich Guy’s real name is Sean Charles Dunn, a D.C. resident who was captured on video hurling a footlong at a federal officer and now faces a felony charge. His likeness has popped up around the city in protest art and in online memes. And, yes, you can buy a shirt.

alert_body: California House Democrats push through redistricting plan to counteract Texas GOP ahead of 2026 midterms
text: The California Democrats’ measure to create a new ballot question is one of three redistricting bills that are expected to pass in the state Senate and House, then reach Gov. Gavin Newsom (D) for his signature today. State voters must then decide in November on a plan that would create five new Democratic-leaning congressional districts.

alert_body: Federal judge rules Alina Habba, Trump’s pick for U.S. attorney in New Jersey, is not serving lawfully
text: The decision means Habba must be disqualified from participating in ongoing cases. But the judge paused his decision to give the Justice Department a chance to appeal.

alert_body: Supreme Court clears way for nearly $800 million in cuts to grants for the National Institutes of Health
text: The justices sided with the Trump administration, which argued that research on diseases in minority, gay and transgender communities was unscientific and went against the president’s efforts to eliminate initiatives related to diversity, equity and inclusion.

alert_body: Trump administration plans ‘continuous vetting’ of all 55 million foreigners with legal U.S. visas
text: The State Department says it intends to scour law enforcement, immigration records and social media for tens of millions of current U.S. visa holders, including for “overstays, criminal activity, threats to public safety … or providing support to a terrorist organization.”

alert_body: White House targets ‘woke’ Smithsonian content in new list that includes exhibitions on race, slavery, immigration and more
text: The list comes two days after the president said he would send his attorneys through the museums, adding that the Smithsonian focused too much on “how bad Slavery was.” Some artists named in the list called it a badge of honor.

alert_body: Erik Menendez is not granted parole. He and his brother, who awaits his hearing, were convicted of killing their parents in 1989.
text: Menendez had been sentenced to life in prison. A parole hearing for his brother, Lyle, is scheduled for Friday. The Menendez family has long claimed the Beverly Hills murders were in self-defense after abuse at the hands of the boys’ father, but prosecutors argued the shotgun slayings were conducted by the siblings for financial gain.

alert_body: Federal judge orders Florida to dismantle Alligator Alcatraz immigrant detention facility in 60 days
text: The order from U.S. District Judge Kathleen Williams hands environmentalists a major win after they clashed with Gov. Ron DeSantis and his administration over the impacts the site was having in the federally protected Everglades. It also deals a blow to what had become a marquee symbol of President Donald Trump’s immigration policy.

alert_body: Famine confirmed in Gaza City region and is projected to spread within weeks, global hunger monitor says
text: More than half a million people are facing catastrophic conditions “characterized by starvation, destitution and death,” according to the Integrated Food Security Phase Classification report.

alert_body: Visa vetting. Smithsonian exhibits. Trump ruling. Gaza famine. Menendez brothers. Hurricanes. Birdsong at night. Catch up now.
text: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

alert_body: FBI searches former Trump national security adviser John Bolton’s suburban Washington home
text: A person familiar with the matter didn’t say what brought investigators to Bolton’s residence in Maryland. Bolton has emerged as a staunch critic of Donald Trump. Earlier this year, the president revoked Bolton’s security clearances and canceled his security detail.

alert_body: 10 questions, and don’t forget the bonus wager! Finish off your week with On the Record.
text: Think you’ve got what it takes to earn a perfect score? Take today’s longer news quiz and complete your point total for the week.

alert_body: Education Department finds George Mason University improperly used race in hiring, seeks apology from president
text: The department also has asked the Virginia university to conduct trainings and revise policy. The university did not immediately respond to the finding, which comes as the Trump administration has scrutinized universities across the country over diversity, equity and inclusion policies.

alert_body: Howard University president to exit after two years; institution’s former leader to return as interim
text: The departure of Ben Vinson III, who has led Howard since 2023, comes days into the start of the new academic year at the historically Black university in the nation’s capital. His final day will be Aug. 31. The interim leader will be former president Wayne A.I. Frederick.

alert_body: Fed’s Powell says changing economic factors ‘may warrant’ interest rate cuts, but doesn’t signal when
text: The central bank chief said a softening labor market combined with continued inflation risks from tariffs and immigration policy made for a challenging environment. President Donald Trump has been pressuring the Fed to lower rates.

alert_body: Republican National Committee elects Trump-backed Joe Gruters as chair
text:
The election of Gruters, a state senator in Florida, ensures that another loyalist of President Donald Trump remains at the helm of the RNC heading into the midterms. 

Gruters succeeds Michael Whatley, who stepped down to run for a U.S. Senate seat in North Carolina.

alert_body: Trump seeks $2 billion to beautify D.C. in latest effort to control city affairs
text:
President Donald Trump, a longtime real estate developer, has falsely claimed he has solved the city’s crime problems. Now he seeks to transform Washington into a place reminiscent of his private golf clubs. 

It is unclear how likely Congress is to grant the funds or whether city leaders will support the effort.

alert_body: Secretary of Defense Pete Hegseth authorizes National Guard to carry weapons in D.C. deployment
text: The 2,000 National Guard members participating in the military deployment President Donald Trump has ordered in Washington, D.C., will “soon be on mission with their service-issued weapons,” the Pentagon said in a statement.

alert_body: Kennedy Center to host the 2026 World Cup draw in December, Trump announces
text: The 2026 World Cup, set to begin in June, will be staged in the United States, Canada and Mexico. Washington will not host matches, but a draw at the Kennedy Center allows the District to join the festivities.

alert_body: Trump administration purge of national security agencies widens with firing of DIA chief Lt. Gen. Jeffrey Kruse
text: Secretary of Defense Pete Hegseth’s sacking of Kruse, the director of the Defense Intelligence Agency, marks the latest removal of a senior military or intelligence officer in a wider purge of national security agencies’ top ranks, according to two people familiar with the matter.

alert_body: Intel’s CEO has agreed to give the U.S. government $10 billion, Trump says
text: The president equated the payment to 10% of the American chipmaker’s value, saying he told CEO Lip-Bu Tan that “it would be good having the United States as your partner” and that “they've agreed to do it.”

alert_body: Kilmar Abrego García is released in Tennessee, lawyer confirms, despite Trump administration’s insistence he should ‘never go free’
text: The Maryland man illegally deported to El Salvador was released Friday as he awaits trial on human smuggling charges. Federal officials obeyed a pair of court orders to release Abrego García and allow him to return to Maryland. Immigration officials may seek to quickly deport him.

alert_body: DOJ releases full transcript, audio from interview with Jeffrey Epstein associate Ghislaine Maxwell
text: Deputy Attorney General Todd Blanche conducted two days of interviews with Maxwell in Florida in July amid growing pressure on the Trump administration to release more information about Epstein, the wealthy sex offender. On Friday, Blanche said he was releasing the interview with Maxwell, who is serving a 20-year sentence for sex trafficking.

alert_body: Lyle Menendez, who killed his parents in their Beverly Hills home, is denied parole alongside his brother
text: The denials are a setback in the campaign to release the brothers, who are serving life sentences for murdering their parents in 1989. The Menendez family has largely supported the siblings, who maintain that they carried out the slayings  in self-defense after suffering alleged physical and sexual abuse at the hands of their father.

alert_body: Texas Senate passes Trump-backed election map
text: In a quick, party-line 18-11 vote that took Democrats by surprise early Saturday, the Republican-controlled chamber approved the map, which aims to help the GOP hold its narrow U.S. House majority in the midterms by creating five new districts in areas Trump won by double digits in 2024. The plan now heads to Gov. Greg Abbott (R), who is expected to swiftly sign it.

text: How many guesses will Keyword take you today? Try to beat the average now.

alert_body: Drowning in cases, an immigration lawyer is ‘tired of losing.’ And his phone keeps ringing.
text: Christopher Kinnison, a lawyer in Alexandria, Louisiana, faces increasing challenges as ICE detentions rise under President Donald Trump. His clients, often detained in rural Louisiana, face high denial rates as he struggles with a backlog of cases, changing policies and remote court hearings.

text: Ask Sahaj: My partner ignored a friend’s racist joke. Is our relationship toast?

alert_body: Pentagon plans military deployment in Chicago as Trump eyes crackdown
text: Officials have weighed mobilizing at least a few thousand members of the National Guard as soon as September in Chicago, while also discussing deploying active-duty troops. The show of force, if approved, could be a model the administration uses in other cities.

text: Crossword and a coffee: Solve the Sunday puzzle now

text: Happiness and meaning are important, but scientists are studying what it means to live a life that’s psychologically rich, with novel experiences, perspective-shifting insights and complexity.

alert_body: What’s really going on in D.C.? White House videos compete with bystanders’.
text: In the weeks since President Donald Trump declared a crime emergency in D.C., the internet has been awash with footage taken on city streets. The videos coming from the White House and the public offer split-screen narratives.

alert_body: It’s not just you — summer really is getting longer. See how temperatures have changed in your town.
text: The hottest stretch of the year is expanding beyond any calendar definition of summer. These regions are experiencing the biggest change.

alert_body: National Guard members in D.C. now carrying weapons
text: Guard members will carry their service-issued weapons, which may include M4 carbine rifles and M17 pistols, and “detentions may occur leading to arrests,” a spokesman from Joint Task Force-D.C., the military mission that includes Guard members from D.C. and six states that are involved in the deployment, said in a statement.
