alert_body: In public letter, FEMA staff warn Trump officials’ actions risk Katrina-level disaster
text: About 150 Federal Emergency Management Agency employees sent a letter Monday to members of Congress and other officials, arguing that the agency’s direction and current leaders’ inexperience harm the agency’s mission and could result in a disaster on the level of Hurricane Katrina. The letter, on which more than two dozen FEMA staff signed their full names, is the latest example of federal employees speaking out against the Trump administration’s actions and policies.

alert_body: Kilmar Abrego García detained by U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement after arriving at the agency’s Baltimore field office
text: The detention comes three days after the undocumented immigrant was freed after a federal judge determined he didn't pose a flight risk or a danger to the community while he awaits trial on human smuggling charges. ICE notified Abrego shortly after his release Friday that the agency could deport him to Uganda within days.

alert_body: A big launch for this network in today’s On the Record
text: Answer now to earn your Monday points.

alert_body: GOP-led House committee is investigating allegations that D.C. police faked lower crime rate data, echoing Justice Department probe
text: The House Oversight Committee is investigating whether D.C. police manipulated data at the direction of department leadership, according to records reviewed by The Washington Post. The inquiry comes on the heels of a Justice Department probe into similar matters and as D.C. officials continue to cite local crime statistics to protest President Donald Trump’s takeover of city law enforcement.

alert_body: Trump signs executive orders cracking down on cashless bail and flag burning
text: President Donald Trump seeks to force Washington, D.C., to abandon its no-cash-bail law and pressure states with similar policies. Another order aims to overturn a Supreme Court decision that said the First Amendment protects flag burning.

alert_body: Star wide receiver Terry McLaurin and Commanders agree on three-year contract extension
text: McLaurin’s extension will pay him $96 million with the chance to escalate, a person familiar with the deal said. The 29-year-old has not practiced all summer as he sought a new deal in line with the league's top receivers. This puts him as the sixth-highest paid receiver in the NFL by average annual salary.

alert_body: Carolyn Hax: Family wonders how to ask childless uncle whether he has a will
text: Carolyn Hax: Family wonders how to ask childless uncle whether he has a will

alert_body: Elon Musk’s xAI sues Apple and OpenAI, alleging they colluded to favor ChatGPT in the App Store over his chatbot Grok
text: The suit takes aim at a deal Apple struck to use OpenAI’s artificial intelligence software on iPhones and other devices after struggling to compete with its own AI features. Musk’s company seeks billions of dollars in damages.

alert_body: Federal judge temporarily bars Kilmar Abrego García’s deportation to Uganda
text: U.S. District Judge Paula Xinis issued the order from the bench Monday, hours after Homeland Security officials detained Abrego during a required check-in at the U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement field office in Baltimore. Xinis said she wants to hear evidence to ensure that the Trump administration will give him an opportunity to contest his deportation to Uganda.

alert_body: House committee subpoenas Epstein estate, requesting ‘birthday book’ allegedly prepared by Maxwell and any ‘client list’
text: House Oversight Committee Chairman James Comer (R-Kentucky) demanded documents from Jeffrey Epstein’s estate that might shed light on the federal sex-trafficking investigation into the financier. The subpoena, which demands documents by Sept. 8, asks for any book gifted by Ghislaine Maxwell to Epstein for his 50th birthday and anything that could be construed as a “client list” and Epstein’s “Black Book” of contacts.

alert_body: Diamond baron Maurice Tempelsman dies at 95. He became a major Democratic donor and drew attention as Jackie Onassis’s companion.
text: Urbane and intensely private, Tempelsman was as comfortable in the palaces of African autocrats as he was visiting the White House or working back channels with U.S. diplomats. He rose to became the largest player in the U.S. diamond market and gained additional notice for his strolls in Central Park with former first lady Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis, his partner from the early 1980s until her death in 1994.

alert_body: Frank Lloyd Wright’s iconic Fallingwater is leaking. See inside the $7 million effort to save it.
text: For the past two years, staff at Wright’s terraced masterpiece in the Pennsylvania woods have found themselves in the middle of a home improvement project on steroids. And they’re doing it all while hewing to strict historic preservation standards and managing the expectations of visitors from around the world.

alert_body: Trump moves to fire Fed governor Lisa Cook over allegations of mortgage fraud, saying there’s ‘sufficient cause’ for removal
text: The president cited his authority to fire governors for cause in a letter posted to Truth Social. The move could lead to a major test of the Federal Reserve’s independence.

alert_body: Australia accuses Iran of directing antisemitic attacks, expels its ambassador
text: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese said Australia’s security agency determined Tehran was behind at least two attacks on Jewish institutions in Sydney and Melbourne.

alert_body: The six factions of Trumpworld: The president melds a contentious coalition

alert_body: Federal judge dismisses Justice Department lawsuit against all 15 of Maryland’s judges over handling of deportations
text: Judge Thomas T. Cullen ruled that the Maryland bench was within its rights to pause deportations for two business days in cases where a habeas corpus petition was filed.

text: Carolyn Hax: Nieces prefer getting cash gifts and not sending thank-you notes

text: The pop star and Kansas City Chiefs tight end have dated since 2023.

alert_body: Trump’s latest attempt to erode the Fed’s independence is dangerous, the Editorial Board writes
text: Frustration with the central bank is understandable, but trying to fire Lisa Cook is not the answer.

alert_body: Trump administration places several FEMA employees on leave after they signed a letter criticizing the agency’s leadership
text: Federal Emergency Management Agency officials informed some staffers that they were no longer on active duty after about 180 current and former employees sent a letter Monday arguing current leaders’ inexperience and approach could result in a disaster on the level of Hurricane Katrina, according to documents reviewed by The Washington Post.

alert_body: U.S. Transportation Department plans to take over D.C.’s Union Station
text: It’s not clear how dramatic the change will be for the transit hub, which connects regional trains and buses to the Metro system. But it is another example of the White House exerting power over the District as National Guard soldiers and federal law enforcement officers continue to patrol the city.

alert_body: D.C. judges and grand jurors push back on Trump policing surge
text: A federal magistrate judge said one arrest in D.C. was preceded by the “most illegal search I’ve seen in my life.” In another case, a grand jury refused three times to issue an indictment against a woman accused of assaulting a federal officer.

alert_body: A draw at the Kennedy Center in today’s On the Record
text: Answer now to earn your Wednesday points.

alert_body: Multiple children injured in shooting at Minneapolis Catholic school, hospital says; police say shooter is no longer a threat
text: Family members of students at Annunciation Catholic School rushed to the scene, which police had cordoned off with vehicles and yellow tape.

alert_body: Grand jury declines to indict D.C. man arrested for throwing a sandwich at federal law enforcement
text: The failure by federal prosecutors to secure an indictment Tuesday is the latest example of President Donald Trump’s surge of policing on the streets of D.C. meeting resistance in the city’s federal courthouse. This month, Sean Charles Dunn, a Justice Department employee, was charged with “assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers and employees of the United States.” Prosecutors could try again to secure a grand jury indictment.

alert_body: Trump administration moves to bar states and nonprofits, such as Red Cross, from helping undocumented immigrants after disasters
text: The new Homeland Security requirements for receiving federal funds have sparked concern among organizations that provide relief in the aftermath of disasters. The rules also say that states and volunteer organizations must comply with immigration officials and enforcement operations.

alert_body: Minneapolis gunman fired on students at worship service, killing 2 children, injuring 17 people before shooting self, officials say
text: The shooter, a man in his early 20s with three weapons, is dead from an apparent self-inflicted gunshot wound, officials said.

alert_body: FDA limits approval for new coronavirus vaccines to those considered high risk
text: Trump administration officials have criticized the previous public health approach to broadly recommend annual coronavirus vaccines. The new approach limits approvals to those ages 65 and older or those with a medical condition that elevates their risk of severe disease. It's unclear if others will be able to access shots.

alert_body: FBI identifies Minneapolis Catholic school shooter, says it is investigating attack as a hate crime and domestic terrorism
text: Two children were killed and more than a dozen people were injured when the shooter opened fire through the windows of a church while children from the adjacent Annunciation Catholic School were attending Mass to mark their first week of school.

alert_body: CDC Director Susan Monarez is being ousted weeks after confirmation to lead health agency, multiple officials say
text: The federal scientist was President Donald Trump’s second choice to lead the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention after he pulled the nomination of former congressman Dave Weldon.

alert_body: Trump administration wants to use military base near Chicago as launchpad for potential ICE operations, officials say
text: Officials at Naval Station Great Lakes acknowledged having received a request from the Department of Homeland Security that seeks “limited support” for Immigration and Customs Enforcement. The discussion comes as the White House contemplates deploying thousands of U.S. troops to Chicago.

alert_body: Trump, Gabbard revoked security clearance of top CIA Russia expert days after Alaska summit with Putin
text: The CIA officer was due to take up a prestigious assignment in Europe approved by CIA Director John Ratcliffe. Instead, she was accused of betraying her oath to the Constitution and abusing public trust in a broad, public purge of 37 current and former officials.

alert_body: CDC director refuses to resign, as her lawyers accuse RFK Jr. of ‘putting millions of American lives at risk’
text: Hours after the Department of Health and Human Services said Susan Monarez is no longer the CDC director, her lawyers said she did not resign and had not been fired. In a fiery statement, the lawyers accused HHS Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. and his department of “weaponizing public health for political gain.” Tumult at the public health agency grew as three senior leaders announced their resignations.

alert_body: Russian strikes pummel Kyiv, killing at least 12 and damaging E.U. building in fiercest attack since Trump-Putin summit
text: The Russian weaponry included drones and ballistic and cruise missiles and were the fiercest attack on Ukraine’s capital since President Donald Trump and President Vladimir Putin’s summit in Alaska failed to produce a ceasefire. Trump has threatened “economic war” on Russia if it doesn’t move toward a negotiated end to the conflict.

alert_body: Jim Irsay, owner of NFL’s Colts, suffered multiple overdoses before he died in May, as a doctor provided opioids and ketamine
text: Irsay spent the last two years of his life in the throes of a relapse that he and Indianapolis Colts executives repeatedly hid from the public, a Washington Post investigation found. This relapse, and his death, came as he was under the care of a “luxury” recovery doctor prescribing Irsay opioids and ketamine.

text: The Trump administration has accused Cook of making false statements on mortgage applications. Cook has yet to respond substantively to the allegations, which have yet to be proved.

text: As the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reeled from the ousting of its director, three senior leaders who resigned in protest told The Washington Post they were asked to participate in an unscientific vaccine recommendation process that they believe could harm the health of Americans.

alert_body: Federal judge blocks Kari Lake from firing the director of Voice of America
text: Judge Royce Lamberth ruled that only a majority vote from the Senate-confirmed board of the broadcaster can fire its director, Michael Abramowitz, dealing a blow to the Trump administration’s effort to dismantle the service.

alert_body: Cold-case killer gets 22 years in prison for 2001 murder of his ex-girlfriend’s mother in Chevy Chase, Maryland
text: Eugene Gligor admitted he murdered Leslie Preer but claimed he doesn’t remember how it happened. And another element remains unknown to authorities: his motive.

alert_body: White House picks top RFK Jr. deputy to be acting CDC director
text: The selection of Jim O'Neill reflects Robert F. Kennedy Jr.'s influence as he seeks to remake federal vaccine policy. It comes a day after the White House fired Susan Monarez, the Senate-confirmed director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, which prompted a series of resignations of other top CDC officials.

alert_body: The U.S. has an ‘impostor nurse’ problem, and it’s grown since the pandemic
text: Authorities in numerous states have reported people falsely claiming to be licensed nurses or working in positions that require a nursing license without valid credentials. Staffing shortages, underfunding and a lack of oversight have exacerbated the problem, one expert said.

alert_body: Trump revokes Kamala Harris’s Secret Service detail, which had been extended by Biden
text: The president’s decision comes as his 2024 Democratic opponent prepares to travel nationwide for a book tour. Federal law gives vice presidents six months of Secret Service protection after they leave office, though President Joe Biden had lengthened her detail into 2026 before he left the White House.

alert_body: How a hacker uncovered the data behind Tesla’s $243 million wrongful death verdict
text: The carmaker long said it didn’t have an electric vehicle’s stored digital account of its fatal 2019 crash involving Autopilot. The way that data finally was discovered is believed to have played into a Florida jury’s recent landmark finding that Tesla was partially liable.

alert_body: In Trump’s latest test of Congress’s spending authority, White House cancels nearly $5 billion in previously approved USAID funding
text: The administration says it can act with or without approval from lawmakers, under a little-tested theory called a “pocket rescission.”

alert_body: Happening now: Do you need a prescription for the new coronavirus vaccines? We’re answering your questions.
text: The Food and Drug Administration narrowed approval of new coronavirus vaccines to those 65 and over or those with conditions that make them more susceptible to severe illness. Meanwhile, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention is reeling after the White House fired its director. What questions do you have about the new vaccine policy and the state of the CDC? The Post’s health team is answering your questions during a live chat now. Send in your questions here.

alert_body: Two Northern Virginia school districts sue Education Department as agency seeks to freeze funding over gender policies
text: The lawsuits filed by Arlington and Fairfax County public school districts come after the Education Department said it would require five Northern Virginia districts to seek reimbursement for certain federal grants, as well as begin the process of pulling other funding, in response to local leaders rejecting a call to change policies that allow students to use facilities like bathrooms and locker rooms that match their gender identity.

alert_body: Republican Sen. Joni Ernst will not seek reelection in Iowa, people familiar with her decision say
text: The decision creates an opportunity for Democrats next year in their long-odds push to regain control of the Senate. Ernst was first elected to the Senate in 2014 and comfortably won reelection in 2020. Iowa has been a staunchly Republican state in recent elections, though the GOP has faced some political headwinds there this year.

alert_body: The 10 best college football towns in the country, according to our sports and travel writers
text: Fall colors. Buzzing student bodies. Alumni reliving glory days. If you visit any one of these towns before kickoff, you’ll feel the magic, and maybe learn a new cheer or two.

alert_body: Missouri’s Republican governor calls a special session to redraw the state’s congressional districts
text: Gov. Mike Kehoe announced a special session next week with the aim of gaining one more GOP seat in the U.S. House of Representatives. President Donald Trump has increased pressure on states to redraw congressional districts in hopes of beefing up his party’s chances of holding onto the House in the 2026 midterms.

alert_body: Trump officials fire more than half a dozen EPA employees for signing letter criticizing the agency's leadership and direction
text: The move to terminate at least seven staffers marks an escalation in the administration’s effort to clamp down on dissent within the federal bureaucracy. EPA leaders had placed a total of 144 employees on leave for signing the letter nearly two months ago. Agency officials confirmed the firings, but did not say how many people had been let go.

alert_body: Federal appeals court strikes down Trump's tariffs, a key part of his economic policy
text: The U.S. Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit ruled that a 1977 law, called the International Emergency Economic Powers Act, or IEEPA, could not be used to impose most of Trump’s tariffs. The law is used in the case of threats against the country.

alert_body: Judge temporarily blocks Trump administration from rapidly deporting most unauthorized immigrants without due process
text: The ruling comes after immigrant rights groups challenged the president’s broad expansion of expedited removal for migrants in the United States illegally and marks a setback for his mass deportation agenda.

text: The Mercator projection, a centuries-old map style from the age of sail, still prevails in the internet age. Here’s what the African Union wants to use instead.

text: Offering calm, disengaged responses — often referred to as the “gray rock method” — has become something of a phenomenon. Experts say the technique might quell conflict in some situations, but it’s not a long-term strategy.

alert_body: Judge orders administration to temporarily halt deportation of hundreds of Guatemalan children
text: A federal judge rushed an emergency hearing after learning that the Trump administration was moving to deport children to Guatemala despite an order she had issued early Sunday. The Justice Department said the government would ground planes carrying the children to their country of origin.

alert_body: Postwar plan for Gaza circulating within the Trump administration envisions 'voluntary' relocation of entire population
text: It's not clear that the 38-page prospectus — which calls for turning Gaza into a trusteeship administered by the United States for at least 10 years while it is transformed into a tourism resort and manufacturing hub — is what President Donald Trump, who has vowed to "take over" the enclave, has in mind. But major elements of it, according to two people familiar with the planning, were designed to make real the president’s vision of a “Riviera of the Middle East.”

alert_body: More than 600 dead in earthquake in Afghanistan, officials say
text: The Taliban-run Interior Ministry said more than 1,500 others were injured after the 6.0-magnitude earthquake struck eastern Afghanistan. Damage and casualties were reported across the region, and the quake was felt in Kabul and neighboring Pakistan.

alert_body: Trump’s deployment of National Guard troops to Los Angeles violated the law, judge rules in case brought by Gov. Gavin Newsom
text: The judge concluded that National Guard troops carried out domestic law enforcement actions, violating federal law. The judge did not order the remaining troops withdrawn but blocked them from certain actions.

text: Carolyn Hax: Grandma’s offhand swipe at adoption gives couple pause

alert_body: Trump intends to move U.S. Space Command headquarters from Colorado to Alabama, reversing Biden-era plan
text: The announcement, expected from President Donald Trump later Tuesday, marks the latest twist in a years-long partisan battle over the agency’s home.

alert_body: Federal judge bars Google from exclusive deals for its search engine but says it can keep Chrome in high-profile monopoly case
text: Judge Amit P. Mehta rejected prosecutors’ call to break up the Silicon Valley giant as he laid out remedies for his finding last year that it has an illegal monopoly in search.

alert_body: D.C. Mayor Bowser welcomes federal law enforcement presence indefinitely, a sign of compliance with Trump
text: President Donald Trump’s federalization of the D.C. police force lasts 30 days and is set to expire next week. Mayor Muriel E. Bowser’s plans may quell a showdown over what happens after that deadline passes.

alert_body: U.S. conducts ‘lethal strike’ on alleged drug vessel in Caribbean, a dramatic escalation as Trump intensifies focus on cartels
text: Administration officials said the operation targeted a boat that departed Venezuela and was operated by a “designated narco-terrorist organization.” It appeared to mark the first known time the Trump administration used deadly force to target illicit drug shipments originating in Latin America.

alert_body: First batch of Epstein files released by Congress
text: The House Oversight and Government Reform Committee released 33,295 pages of documents related to convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein. The committee said it was the first in a series of expected releases as a bipartisan group of lawmakers seeks more transparency from the Trump administration on the subject.

alert_body: At an ICE career expo, a Marine veteran and a former MMA fighter are among thousands vying to carry out Trump’s deportation agenda
text: The administration is aiming to hire 10,000 new immigration officers next year, drumming up interest through militaristic branding and a signing bonus of up to $50,000 for top recruits. Applicants said they were not deterred by waning public support for the president's hardline approach.

alert_body: Federal appellate panel rejects Trump’s deportations under Alien Enemies Act
text: The appellate panel ruled Tuesday that President Donald Trump unlawfully invoked the centuries-old wartime law to deport Venezuelan migrants, finding no invasion or “predatory incursion” had occurred to justify using the statute to fast-track migrant removals. The decision is widely expected to be appealed to the Supreme Court.

alert_body: Florida moves to end vaccine mandates to attend school, the first state to do so
text: Florida Surgeon General Joseph A. Ladapo’s stances on vaccines and other measures have drawn criticism from public health experts and advocates, who have warned that the overhaul of vaccine policies could cause a resurgence of preventable diseases.

alert_body: House Republicans vote to establish new subcommittee to reinvestigate Jan. 6
text: Lawmakers slipped a resolution into a rule on the House floor that would establish a subcommittee to revisit the events of Jan. 6, 2021, in which pro-Trump protesters stormed the Capitol aiming to prevent Joe Biden's certification as president. Republicans have complained that the previous probe was biased against President Donald Trump, who has repeatedly denied he lost the 2020 election.

alert_body: U.S. could have stopped boat allegedly trafficking drugs from Venezuela but Trump chose to blow it up, Rubio says
text: The strike Tuesday on the vessel in the Caribbean, which U.S. officials said killed 11 people, was intended to send a message, Secretary of State Marco Rubio told reporters. “Instead of interdicting it, on the president’s orders, we blew it up,” he said. “And it’ll happen again.”

alert_body: Harvard wins court battle against Trump; administration cannot withhold federal funding, judge rules
text: A federal judge in Boston ruled that the Trump administration illegally withheld billions from the Ivy League school for alleged violations of rules against antisemitism. The administration is expected to appeal.

alert_body: A $1.4 billion Powerball win sounds life-changing. Here’s the catch.
text: Sudden wealth might seem like a dream come true, but it can’t shield you from poor choices, says our personal finance columnist.

alert_body: House Republicans will seek to permanently overhaul criminal justice in D.C. and further restrict home rule
text: One of the draft bills would remove the locally elected D.C. attorney general and replace that official with a presidential appointee. The effort would represent a large step backward in the city's quest to expand its autonomy.

alert_body: Texas moves to allow anyone to sue abortion pill prescribers, distributors in effort to stop flow of shipments from blue states
text: Gov. Greg Abbott (R) is expected to sign a bill that would allow residents to sue doctors, pill-makers and distributors that supply the drugs to Texans.

alert_body: Trump administration appeals lower-court ruling that invalidated his tariffs, potentially setting up blockbuster Supreme Court case
text: The Supreme Court will now decide whether to hear the administration’s appeal to overturn a ruling that voided most of President Donald Trump’s tariffs on goods from dozens of nations. It could set up a case with huge implications for consumers, businesses, the U.S. economy and global trade.

alert_body: Vaccine mandates. Trump vs. Harvard. Epstein victims. Abortion pills. Putin hot mic. NFL kickoff. Toilet scrolling. Catch up now.

alert_body: Senate Democrats call for RFK Jr.’s resignation before he faces a grilling on vaccine policy. Follow live coverage of the hearing.
text: Health and Human Services Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. is appearing before senators for the first time after turmoil at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. The White House fired CDC director Susan Monarez after she resisted pressure from Kennedy to change vaccine policy, and three top CDC leaders resigned in protest. Calls for Kennedy's resignation have mounted from Democratic lawmakers, public health advocacy organizations and current and former HHS employees.

alert_body: This ‘beautiful locale’ is the star of today’s On the Record
text: Answer now to earn your Thursday points.

alert_body: Giorgio Armani dies at 91. The designer’s streamlined fashions ruled the red carpet for years.
text: Giorgio Armani’s suits and couture gowns were a staple at awards shows. He debuted his first collection at age 40 in 1975, bringing elegance and refinement to the art of the power suit and revolutionizing the way modern men and women dress. “Elegance doesn’t mean being noticed,” he said. “It means being remembered.”

alert_body: Trump’s Federal Reserve pick plans to keep his White House job while serving on central bank, in unusual threat to Fed independence
text: White House economic adviser Stephen Miran, if confirmed to the Federal Reserve, would not resign but would take a leave of absence from the White House, making him the first modern-day Federal Reserve Board member to maintain ties to the White House.

alert_body: D.C. attorney general sues Trump over National Guard deployment, calling it an illegal ‘military occupation’
text: The lawsuit seeks to force President Donald Trump to withdraw the nearly 2,300 National Guard members stationed in the nation’s capital. D.C. Attorney General Brian Schwalb said the involuntary deployment has infringed on the District’s limited autonomy.

alert_body: Pentagon approves use of Chicago-area Navy base for ICE and possible military operations
text: The Pentagon has approved the use of Naval Station Great Lakes, on the outskirts of Chicago, as a staging ground from which the Trump administration can launch operations against undocumented immigrants, said two defense officials familiar with the issue. If deployed, National Guard or active-duty service members could also be housed at the facility.

text: Carolyn Hax: Drugged by a friend and spinning — in both senses

alert_body: Justice Department issues subpoenas targeting Fed governor Lisa Cook in criminal probe, intensifying Trump’s efforts to oust her
text: The White House has accused Cook of falsifying mortgage records to lenders as the Trump administration builds a legal and political case to remove her from the central bank’s board. A federal judge is considering Cook’s request to temporarily block President Donald Trump’s move and keep her on the board, which meets mid-September to consider interest rates.

alert_body: RFK Jr. clashed with a GOP senator over the availability of coronavirus vaccines, and other takeaways from his fiery hearing
text: Health and Human Services Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. on Thursday defended his tenure in a roughly three-hour Senate hearing, following upheaval at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and frustration with his approach to vaccines. Here are the biggest takeaways from his testimony.

alert_body: Trump to change name of Defense Department to Department of War, a title the White House says more accurately reflects its mission
text: The president is expected to sign an executive order Friday to make the change that "will sharpen the focus of this Department on our national interest and signal to adversaries America’s readiness to wage war to secure its interests," according to a document describing the forthcoming order obtained by The Washington Post. It's unclear if he can permanently change the name without legislation from Congress.

alert_body: The health risks from plastics almost nobody knows about
text: Plastic chemicals, known as phthalates, are everywhere. The Washington Post reviewed more than 50 studies and interviewed more than two dozen scientists, former regulators and industry officials to document how the chemicals are eroding health in unexpected ways.

alert_body: Congress not planning a vote to extend Trump’s 30-day D.C. police takeover
text: In allowing the Trump administration’s grip on D.C. police to come to an end, Congress closes one chapter in the tussle between local and federal officials vying for control of public safety in the capital. But for now, it appears unlikely that fewer federal agents or camouflage-clad troops will patrol city streets.

alert_body: Caitlin Clark will miss remainder of the WNBA season with injury
text: The Indiana Fever star's second season ends with her having appeared in just 13 games. Clark, who helped supercharge interest in the WNBA, has not played since July 15 as she has dealt with groin and ankle injuries. The Fever remains in playoff position but has been decimated by injuries and is not expected to contend for a title.

text: Two 17-year-olds have been charged as adults in D.C. Superior Court with first-degree murder while armed, Pirro said at a news conference Friday. A third suspect remains at large. Officials have said Eric Tarpinian-Jachym, who interned for Rep. Ron Estes (R-Kansas), was shot by a group of people who exited a car and opened fire.

alert_body: AI firm Anthropic agrees to pay landmark $1.5 billion settlement to book authors and publishers
text: The company behind the chatbot Claude agreed to pay about $3,000 per book to avoid trial over claims it improperly downloaded millions of titles.

alert_body: Judge halts Trump officials from ending special status for Venezuelans and Haitians
text: The decision from a federal judge in California could shield hundreds of thousands of people from possible deportation. DHS Secretary Kristi L. Noem had argued that conditions had improved enough in both countries for people to return, a finding that contradicted the State Department’s own travel warnings.

alert_body: Trump’s rebranding of the Defense Department as the War Department is a worthy blow against euphemism, the Editorial Board writes
text: Perhaps the new name can be followed by clearer thinking about the military’s role at home and abroad.

text: The state and city will deploy more resources to violence interruption groups and state prosecutors through a partnership that Gov. Wes Moore and Mayor Brandon Scott say has driven Baltimore’s homicide count to a 50-year low.

alert_body: Davey Johnson dies at 82. The former Washington Nationals manager guided the New York Mets to the World Series title in 1986.
text: Johnson led the Nationals from 2011 to 2013, including their breakthrough 2012 season, when they reached the postseason for the first time. He also starred as a player with the Baltimore Orioles, winning the World Series in 1966 and 1970.

alert_body: After life-altering brain surgery, a songwriter’s creativity flourished
text: Removing a piece of his brain, Mike Frazier and his doctors thought, was his best option for combating a condition that affects about 1 percent of adults in the United States and tens of millions of people worldwide — but that is still often misunderstood and misdiagnosed.

alert_body: West Point alumni group cancels award ceremony for Tom Hanks as Trump-era political controversies grip military academy
text: Hanks, who starred in “Saving Private Ryan” and other films depicting U.S. service members and who has for decades advocated for veterans, was to receive a prestigious award from the West Point alumni association at an event this month. The decision to cancel the ceremony follows political moves that have rattled the military institution since President Donald Trump’s return to power.

alert_body: Aryna Sabalenka of Belarus wins second straight U.S. Open championship, defeating American Amanda Anisimova
text: It is the fourth Grand Slam title for Sabalenka, the top-ranked player in the world. Anisimova, who also finished as the runner-up at Wimbledon this year, had been seeking her first Grand Slam championship.

alert_body: Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba announces resignation after two crushing parliamentary defeats
text: Ishiba’s move exacerbates an unusual period of political uncertainty in Japan, a major U.S. security ally in Asia, as the ruling party has lost its coalition majority in both legislative chambers after governing almost continuously since 1955.

alert_body: California Gov. Gavin Newsom won’t stop mocking Trump online, seeking to position himself as de facto head of Democrats' resistance
text: Influencers on both the left and the right have discussed Newsom online more than any other potential 2028 presidential contender since President Donald Trump’s inauguration, according to a Washington Post analysis. The attention has been driven by his response to immigration raids in Los Angeles, his efforts to counter a Republican redistricting push and, most recently, his mocking impersonations of Trump’s social media style.

alert_body: How to get a complainer to stop, according to a therapist
text: Complaining can foster camaraderie and establish common ground, but when it becomes excessive, it can annoy listeners and wreck relationships. Here are five ways to cope.

alert_body: Carlos Alcaraz of Spain wins U.S. Open, defeating Italy’s Jannik Sinner in third Grand Slam final between the rivals this year
text: Alcaraz and Sinner became the first duo to face each other three times in a Grand Slam title match in a single season in the Open era. Alcaraz, who now has two U.S. Open championships and six total Grand Slams to his name, won this year’s French Open, while Sinner earned the Wimbledon title.

alert_body: Shooting attack on a bus in Jerusalem kills at least five people
text: Other people were injured after two attackers opened fire at a bus stop in north Jerusalem, according to Israel’s emergency services. The attackers were also killed at the scene, the Israeli police said. The Israeli military said troops had been deployed to “thwart terrorism and strengthen the defense effort.” Hamas praised the shooting and said it was “a natural response to the occupation’s crimes.”

alert_body: Trump administration asks Supreme Court to allow it to freeze billions in foreign aid
text: The emergency request could set up a major test of the president’s assertion that he has the unilateral authority to block spending budgeted by Congress. The filing comes after a federal appeals court upheld a preliminary injunction requiring Trump officials to spend the money for food, medicine and development assistance before it begins to expire on Sept. 30, the end of the fiscal year.

alert_body: Meta suppressed research on child safety, employees say. The company denies the allegations.

A Senate Judiciary subcommittee is set to discuss the allegations, which Meta denies, at a hearing Tuesday.

alert_body: Trump can fire a Democratic FTC commissioner while lawsuit proceeds, Supreme Court chief justice rules
text: Supreme Court Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr.’s ruling comes after an appeals court found last week that Commissioner Rebecca Slaughter could be reinstated to her job because President Donald Trump had fired her “without cause.”

alert_body: Trump loses his effort to appeal $83 million judgment in writer E. Jean Carroll’s defamation case against him
text: A federal appeals court Monday upheld a jury’s $83.3 million judgment against President Donald Trump in a lawsuit brought by Carroll. She had accused Trump in 2019 of sexually assaulting her two decades earlier.

alert_body: Supreme Court says Trump can resume immigration raids in L.A. area for now, overturning a ruling that found race-based targeting
text: The Supreme Court overturned a lower-court ruling that curtailed Los Angeles-area detentions after finding federal agents were indiscriminately targeting people based on race and other factors.

alert_body: French Parliament votes to oust prime minister, deepening Macron’s woes as government collapses for second time in under a year
text: The French National Assembly voted “no confidence” in Prime Minister François Bayrou, which will force his resignation. The decision exacerbates the political problems of President Emmanuel Macron, who lost his parliamentary majority after calling snap elections in June 2024.

alert_body: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth makes unannounced trip to Puerto Rico as Pentagon eyes island to assist drug cartel crackdown
text: The Pentagon is weighing plans to make Puerto Rico a part of its operations in Latin America, possibly conducting military flights out of the island territory, said two U.S. officials who spoke on the condition of anonymity. The effort includes the possible deployment of fighter jets to the island, one of the officials said.

alert_body: Congress receives documents it subpoenaed from Jeffrey Epstein’s estate, including book allegedly made for his 50th birthday
text: The House Oversight Committee on Monday received documents from the estate of the sex offender as part of its broader probe into the federal sex-trafficking investigation of Epstein. Epstein’s jailed associate, Ghislaine Maxwell, allegedly gifted the book to him when he turned 50.

alert_body: Murdoch family resolves dispute over ownership of media empire in billion-dollar deal
text: Lachlan Murdoch, whose politics are in line with those of his 94-year-old father, will remain in control after Rupert Murdoch’s death, with three other siblings splitting a $3.3 billion settlement.

alert_body: White House launches stepped up immigration enforcement operation in Chicago as Trump vows a broader crackdown on violent crime
text: Authorities said “Operation Midway Blitz” is part of Trump’s efforts to target “sanctuary cities” that limit cooperation with the federal government. Democrats denounced the action as immigrant advocates said several people in heavily Hispanic communities had already been detained Monday.

alert_body: Oliver North quietly married his former secretary Fawn Hall, four decades after their roles in the Iran-contra scandal
text: The couple tied the knot on Aug. 27 in Virginia, according to a marriage license obtained by The Washington Post. As a National Security Council staffer under President Ronald Reagan, North was accused of illegally arranging the sale of U.S. weapons to Iran to fund a secret war against communists in Nicaragua. Hall, his young secretary at the time, had shred documents and even smuggled evidence out of the office.

alert_body: Inflation wiped out income gains in 2024, but richest 10 percent of households got richer, census finds
text: Most Americans’ household income remained steady last year, but women and Black people lost ground, the U.S. Census Bureau said Tuesday.

text: The far-reaching case is expected to determine the fate of a cornerstone of President Donald Trump’s economic agenda and could alter the course of the U.S. economy and global trade.

alert_body: Fired CDC director Susan Monarez, who clashed with RFK Jr. over vaccines, will testify before Senate next week
text: The hearing will be Monarez’s first public appearance to address the tumult at the CDC. She has said Health and Human Services Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. pressured her to alter vaccine policies and fire staff. Kennedy told senators last week that Monarez lied about their interactions and said she was untrustworthy.

alert_body: Federal judge temporarily blocks Trump’s firing of Federal Reserve board member Lisa Cook
text: In a setback for the president, the judge ruled that Cook had shown strong evidence that the effort to dismiss her was illegal. The board will meet next week to consider an interest rate cut.

alert_body: Poland says it shot down Russian drones that violated its airspace while attacking targets in Ukraine
text: Russia’s actions posed “a real threat” to Polish citizens, the Polish military’s Operational Command said.

text: Detailed analysis of images of speckled rocks found by NASA’s Perseverance rover has confirmed a “potential biosignature.”

alert_body: In new memoir, Kamala Harris says it was ‘recklessness’ to defer to Joe Biden’s decision to run at age 80
text: In her forthcoming book, “107 Days,” Harris said she “perhaps” should have weighed in but worried it would have looked “incredibly self-serving” and disloyal for her to do as Biden’s vice president. She also wrote about not feeling supported by his staff.

text: Former acting FBI director Brian Driscoll alleged in the federal lawsuit that a Trump administration official asked questions including: “Who did you vote for?,” “When did you start supporting President Trump?” and “Have you voted for a Democrat in the last five elections?”

alert_body: Right-wing activist Charlie Kirk shot at Utah college event, two people familiar with matter say
text: Kirk is the founder of Turning Point USA, an organization for young conservatives. He was speaking at an event at Utah Valley University. The school said the suspect was in custody, according to parents whose children received an email from the university.

alert_body: Conservative activist Charlie Kirk dies at 31 after he was shot onstage at Utah college event, Trump says
text: Kirk, the founder of Turning Point USA, was shot while speaking at an event at Utah Valley University.

alert_body: Person of interest in Charlie Kirk shooting is in custody, Utah governor says
text: Utah Gov. Spencer Cox (R) said at a news conference that the person is being interviewed by officials. Cox said the shooting was a “political assassination” and vowed to hold the killer “accountable to the furthest extent of the law.”

alert_body: Charlie Kirk, dead at 31, leveraged his debate skills to create viral moments that captured audiences across the political spectrum
text: The Turning Point USA founder had an audience of millions of fervent conservative fans and fierce liberal critics, emerging as one of the most prominent — and often controversial — voices in the age of Donald Trump.

alert_body: South Koreans detained at Georgia Hyundai plant are headed home, but Trump offered to let them stay and train Americans, Seoul says
text: The 316 South Koreans who were arrested at the Hyundai-LG plant in Georgia are now on their way home. The raid and the treatment of the workers could make South Korean companies “very hesitant” about operating in the United States, the country’s president said.

alert_body: Inflation picked up in August, as Trump’s tariffs continue to pressure prices across more of the economy
text: The hotter inflation data, released by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, combined with a weakening labor market, presents a tricky decision for the Federal Reserve, which will consider interest rate cuts at a meeting next week.

alert_body: Charlie Kirk’s shooter remains at large, but investigators say they have footage of a suspect and recovered a rifle
text: Investigators have video footage of the shooter, but they do not plan to release it at this time, a Utah official said at a news conference. They also have found what they believe to be the weapon used to kill Kirk. Follow our live coverage.

alert_body: Ex-Brazilian president Jair Bolsonaro found guilty in 2022 coup and assassination plot to stay in power
text: Brazil’s supreme court ruled the right-wing former president attempted a military coup to reverse his 2022 election loss, a plot that included plans to assassinate President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, the man who defeated him. President Donald Trump, a Bolsonaro ally and friend, imposed tariffs on Brazilian products and sanctions on individual justices in July to pressure them to drop the prosecution, which he called a witch hunt.

alert_body: A single exercise session may slow cancer cell growth, a new study shows
text: The study involved 32 women who had survived breast cancer. After a single session of interval training or weightlifting, their blood contained higher levels of certain molecules, and those factors helped put the brakes on laboratory-grown breast cancer cells.

alert_body: Republicans change Senate rules to speed up confirmation of Trump nominees as nearly 150 await votes
text: Senate Republicans invoked the “nuclear option” to change the chamber’s rules to allow all executive branch nominees — with the exception of Cabinet posts and judges — to be approved in groups and with less debate. Democrats had drawn out the process of voting on President Donald Trump’s nominees because they argue the nominees are unqualified.

alert_body: Officials release new video of suspect fleeing in Charlie Kirk shooting, still lack a name or location
text: Law enforcement released a new video showing a person climbing down from the edge of a roof, dropping to the ground and moving across a grassy area near a parking lot. Officials said they had still been unable to find or name the person.

alert_body: Trump says National Guard will be deployed in Memphis to fight crime
text: President Donald Trump said during an interview on Fox News that Memphis will be the next city in which the National Guard is tapped following the deployment in D.C. Trump had previously floated deploying the Guard in Chicago but state and local officials have resisted.

alert_body: Trump health officials plan to link coronavirus vaccines to 25 child deaths, alarming career scientists
text: The data is set to be included in a presentation next week to the CDC vaccine advisory committee that is considering new coronavirus vaccine recommendations, according to several people familiar with the situation. The data appears based on reports to a federal database that is not designed to assess whether vaccines caused deaths. The move has alarmed career scientists who say that coronavirus vaccines have been extensively studied, including in children, and that dangers of the virus itself are being underplayed.

alert_body: Man fatally shot by ICE officer in Chicago after allegedly resisting arrest
text: The Department of Homeland Security said Friday that a federal immigration officer fatally shot a man in the Chicago area during an attempted arrest after the man drove his vehicle toward the law enforcement officials, hitting one of them.

alert_body: Israeli intelligence agency balked at Netanyahu’s strike in Qatar
text: The Mossad had planned a ground operation targeting Hamas leaders but declined to execute it, forcing Israel to carry out the unsuccessful airstrike, Israelis say.

alert_body: EPA proposes that companies no longer be required to report their planet-warming emissions
text: The Environmental Protection Agency’s proposal, published Friday, amounts to a major regulatory rollback that would eliminate the primary means of tracking climate goals. EPA Administrator Lee Zeldin described it as a cost-cutting measure that would save businesses up to $2.4 billion.

alert_body: Who’s more sensitive to pain, men or women? The answer may surprise you.
text: It is a common misconception that because women are able to give birth and routinely deal with sometimes agonizing period cramps, they are somehow better able to tolerate pain than men. Nothing could be further from the truth. But the good news is: As we learn more about how pain processing can vary between men and women, it might lead to better treatments.

alert_body: 1 in 6 U.S. parents are skipping or delaying vaccines for their children, according to a Post-KFF poll
text: Americans who are choosing to skip or delay vaccines for their children are more likely to home-school their children, be White and very religious, identify as Republican or be under 35, according to a Washington Post-KFF poll that sheds new light on what drives vaccine hesitancy. The survey shows that 1 in 6 parents have delayed or skipped some vaccines for their children, excluding for coronavirus or flu.

text: The 22-year-old suspect appeared to have confessed to friends in an online chat shortly before turning himself in to law enforcement, according to two people familiar with the chat and screenshots obtained by The Washington Post. “Hey guys, I have bad news for you all,” said a message from an account belonging to the suspect on the online platform Discord. “It was me at UVU yesterday. im sorry for all of this.”

alert_body: U.S. forces kill three alleged drug smugglers from Venezuela in latest military strike, Trump says
text: The operation, which President Donald Trump said occurred in international waters, marks the second time this month that the U.S. military has unleashed deadly force in the region. The president claimed those targeted on Monday were carrying illegal drugs bound for the United States.

alert_body: JD Vance, hosting ‘The Charlie Kirk Show,’ says prominent liberal foundations contribute to political violence

A White House official said the administration has been considering trying to strip groups of their tax-exempt status.

alert_body: Eleanor Holmes Norton should not run for reelection, Donna Brazile writes

alert_body: Trump officials order removal of exhibits related to slavery at multiple national parks, including photo of enslaved man’s scars

The removal orders come in response to President Donald Trump’s March executive order directing the Interior Department to eliminate information that reflects a “corrosive ideology” that disparages historic Americans.

alert_body: Appeals court allows Federal Reserve governor Lisa Cook to keep her job
text: Ahead of the central bank’s key meeting setting interest rates, a divided three-judge panel of the U.S. District Court of Appeals for the D.C. Circuit declined to overturn a preliminary injunction by a federal judge who ruled President Donald Trump could not fire Cook. The ruling is expected to be quickly appealed to the Supreme Court.

alert_body: Senate confirms White House economic adviser Stephen Miran to the Federal Reserve ahead of interest rate meeting
text: Miran said he would take a leave but not resign from his post as chair of the White House Council of Economic Advisers, becoming the first White House official to simultaneously serve on the board of the central bank in 90 years.

text: The Israeli military launched the early stages of the offensive to seize Gaza City overnight, an Israeli military official said. Palestinians in the beleaguered enclave said they faced hours of relentless heavy bombardment.

Yet he forged an even more profound legacy as president and founder of the Sundance Institute, providing a vital platform for outside-the-system filmmakers.

Mangione will still face a trial on murder in the second degree and other related counts. Mangione also faces federal charges related to Brian Thompson’s Dec. 4 killing.

alert_body: ICE’s own inspectors say its giant Texas facility at Ft. Bliss has violated dozens of immigrant detention standards

The report raises significant concerns about the safety of workers and detainees at one of the Trump administration’s marquee immigration projects.

alert_body: Education Department to partner with conservative groups to create patriotic civics programs for America's 250th anniversary
text: Dozens of conservative groups, including Turning Point USA, founded by Charlie Kirk, will work with the Trump administration to create civics programming that will promote patriotism ahead of America's 250th anniversary. It is unusual for a civics initiative to not include liberals, experts said.

alert_body: $3.7 billion deal to build new Washington Commanders stadium and redevelop old RFK site gets final approval from D.C. Council

alert_body: 3 police officers killed, 2 wounded in a shooting in southern Pennsylvania
text: Police responding to a domestic investigation in York County shot and killed the suspect, whom authorities did not identify. Authorities did not give a motive for the shooting, which Gov. Josh Shapiro described as “absolutely tragic” at a news conference Wednesday evening.

The recommendation goes to the acting head of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, who will decide whether to make it the official government recommendation.

alert_body: Texas A&M president resigns in wake of instructor’s firing over gender teachings
text: President Mark A. Welsh III, a retired four-star general who later served as a member of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, is stepping down. alert_body: Most Americans critical of Trump on crime, economy and other issues, Post-Ipsos poll finds
text: A Washington Post-Ipsos poll paints a downbeat picture of Donald Trump’s presidency eight months into his second term. Despite a slight uptick in his overall approval rating compared with April, Americans disapprove of his performance on a broad range of issues — crime, the economy, immigration, foreign wars — and all by double-digit margins. Republicans hold advantages over Democrats on trust to handle crime, the economy and immigration, though a majority of Americans still say they want Democrats to control the next Congress “as a check on Trump.”

alert_body: House passes bill to avert government shutdown, but it’s expected to stall in Senate

alert_body: Israel killed 31 journalists in strike on Yemen newspaper complex, press freedom group says

alert_body: Trump administration set to tie Tylenol to autism risk, officials say
text: Federal officials have been reviewing a possible link between Tylenol's early use in pregnancy and an increased risk of autism in children — a connection that researchers say needs more studies to draw conclusions. They are also expected to tout a lesser-known drug, leucovorin, as a potential treatment. President Donald Trump has prioritized the initiatives, although outside researchers have called for further study.

alert_body: President Donald Trump, Vice President JD Vance to speak at memorial for conservative activist Charlie Kirk. Follow our coverage.
text: The president, vice president and Kirk's widow, Erika, will speak to the tens of thousands of supporters gathered to mourn Kirk and highlight the contributions his organization, Turning Point USA, has made to the modern Republican Party. The scale and security of the event is on par with a state funeral, and the attendance of high-level political figures is notable, given that Kirk was a private citizen who was not well-known to a large swath of Americans until his death.

alert_body: Trump, allies cast Charlie Kirk as ‘martyr’ whose legacy can shape GOP future at memorial that blended religious fervor, politics
text: Republicans extolled conservative activist Charlie Kirk at a memorial Sunday as a religious leader of almost biblical stature who transformed the party and was critical to delivering the presidency to Donald Trump — and they predicted that Kirk’s slaying will galvanize their political movement for generations to come.

alert_body: Charlie Kirk’s Christianity-infused politics appear poised to ascend within the GOP, and other takeaways from his memorial
text: Kirk was not a household name before his death, but the right-wing movement he built could become a dominant part of the Republican Party, according to more than a dozen speakers and leaders of the Trump administration who memorialized him Sunday. Here are takeaways from the hours-long service in Arizona.

text: The justices overturned a lower-court injunction that reinstated Rebecca Slaughter to her position with the agency that oversees antitrust and consumer protection issues while litigation over her removal works its way through the courts. The high court also announced it will hear arguments on overturning a 90-year-old precedent that allows Congress to restrict a president's power to remove members of independent agencies.

alert_body: Anti-ICE messaging was found on rounds in Dallas ICE facility shooting that killed 1 person and injured 2, officials say

The decision, confirmed by two people familiar with the situation, comes after the Nationals fired longtime general manager Mike Rizzo and manager Dave Martinez in July.

alert_body: As Texas flooded, key staff say FEMA’s leader could not be reached — part of a broader pattern of inaccessibility
text: After the deadly July floods in Texas, key Federal Emergency Management Agency staff members say they could not reach acting administrator David Richardson for a period of roughly 24 hours as they scrambled to coordinate a response. The Washington Post reviewed internal records that support current and former FEMA officials’ claims that Richardson is frequently inaccessible.

alert_body: China, the world’s largest greenhouse gas emitter, pledges its first-ever reduction target
text: China committed to reducing its greenhouse gas emissions by 7 percent to 10 percent over the next decade. Climate experts widely described China’s commitment as insufficient and said they hoped the country would out-perform its new target.

alert_body: Justice Department will seek to indict former FBI director James B. Comey, fulfilling a demand from Trump
text: After the U.S. attorney for the Eastern District of Virginia resigned under pressure, President Donald Trump replaced him with a White House aide and demanded that Attorney General Pam Bondi seek criminal charges against Comey. Virginia prosecutors plan to ask a grand jury in Richmond to indict him on allegations that he lied to Congress, people familiar with the matter say.

alert_body: Trump should fix the U.N., not just grandstand, John Bolton writes

text:
The memo directs agencies to consider firing employees working on any program that is not funded by another law, such as Republicans’ One Big Beautiful Bill Act, and which does not align with the president’s priorities.

Government funding will run out next week if Congress doesn't act.

Comey is charged with making a false statement to Congress and with obstructing Congress.
A federal grand jury declined to indict him on a third count sought by prosecutors. The charges involve the FBI's investigation of Russia's efforts to interfere with the 2016 election and his testimony before the Senate Judiciary Committee in September 2020.  He has denied wrongdoing.

alert_body: Robert Barnett dies at 79. The Washington lawyer was a consummate political insider, with clients on both sides of the aisle.
text:
Barnett, a partner at Williams & Connolly, represented corporations as well as public officials, many of whom he helped transition into the private sector.

He served as Hillary Clinton’s personal attorney beginning in 1992 and represented clients including Washington Post journalist Bob Woodward, former vice president Dan Quayle and Democratic strategist James Carville.

This move comes more than a week after Kimmel’s comments about the shooting of Kirk angered supporters of the conservative activist and following ABC reinstating the program Tuesday.

alert_body: New details emerge about Pete Hegseth’s unusual order to gather top generals and admirals for ‘warrior ethos’ speech
text: The defense secretary has summoned hundreds of top military brass to fly in from around the world for what is planned as a short address on the “warrior ethos,” according to multiple people familiar with the order to gather in-person at the Quantico Marine Corps base in Virginia on Tuesday. The Pentagon has refused to comment on the nature of the meeting, alarming and confusing top military officers.

alert_body: Nexstar stations will join Sinclair in broadcasting Jimmy Kimmel again, bringing him back to his former full audience

The reinstating of Kimmel's show to Nexstar and Sinclair stations brings him back to his former audience following the controversy.

alert_body: Supreme Court clears way for Trump administration to freeze billions in foreign aid for now

The ruling is a victory for the president’s push to exert greater control over federal spending.

alert_body: “I went nose-to-nose with a mountain lion. It was scary — and magical,” Post columnist writes.
text: Mountain lions used to range across the entire continental U.S., but now they are limited to the west coast. Returning these carnivores east of the Mississippi could help maintain entire ecosystems by keeping animals lower down the food chain in check, limiting invasive species, reducing fire danger, boosting biodiversity and even potentially combating climate change.

alert_body: YouTube will pay $24.5 million to settle Trump lawsuit over company’s decision in 2021 to remove his account after Jan. 6 attack
text: The agreement says that President Donald Trump has directed YouTube to contribute $22 million of the settlement to help construct the new White House ballroom. The rest of the money will go to a handful of other plaintiffs who accused YouTube of censoring them. The settlement follows similar deals earlier this year with social platforms Meta and X, which also suspended or blocked Trump’s accounts after the Jan. 6, 2021, attacks.

alert_body: Lally Weymouth dies at 82. The Post journalist, a member of the storied Graham family, interviewed presidents and prime ministers.
text:
As the granddaughter, daughter, sister and mother of five different Washington Post publishers, Weymouth moved in social circles that helped shape American media and government.
While her younger brother Donald E. Graham was tapped to succeed their mother, Katharine Graham, as publisher of The Post in the 1970s, Weymouth initially pursued a career outside the paper. She joined The Post in 1986, eventually rising to become a senior associate editor.

alert_body: Trump can deploy National Guard in Portland, appeals court rules
text: A federal judge appointed by President Donald Trump had blocked him from sending federalized National Guard members to Oregon’s largest city.

alert_body: Demolition of White House facade begins, contradicting Trump’s claim that addition wouldn’t interfere with current structure
text: Construction teams Monday demolished a portion of the East Wing, with a backhoe ripping through the structure, according to a photo shared with The Washington Post and two people who witnessed the activity. The ballroom project, long desired by President Donald Trump, is estimated to cost $250 million.

alert_body: Former FBI director James B. Comey asks judge to dismiss criminal case against him, calling it vindictive
text: In court filings, Comey’s attorneys accused President Donald Trump of personally instigating the case against their client. When several prosecutors refused to proceed, the attorneys wrote, Trump installed a loyalist in a key position to ensure that charges would be filed.

alert_body: Two more teens charged in August attack on DOGE staffer that propelled Trump’s D.C. takeover
text: An 18- and a 19-year-old face charges including robbery and assault for their alleged role in the Aug. 3 attack on Edward Coristine — a 19-year-old software engineer known as “Big Balls” — and another person at a nearby gas station, U.S. Attorney for D.C. Jeanine Pirro announced Monday. Earlier this month, two 15-year-olds were sentenced to probation for their role in the incidents.

alert_body: Six of nine top colleges have rejected the Trump administration’s funding deal ahead of Monday deadline
text: Despite strong pressure from the White House, including a Friday call, colleges and universities are largely rejecting President Donald Trump’s offer of preferential treatment for funding in exchange for compliance with his ideological priorities. On Monday, the University of Arizona and Vanderbilt University did not accept the deal, but said they were open to more discussion.

alert_body: Four surprising things that may reduce your risk of Parkinson’s
text: Research on Parkinson’s is revealing several risk factors related to our lifestyles and environment, and you can act on some of them.

alert_body: The Toronto Blue Jays advanced to the Fall Classic for first time since 1993, where they will take on the Los Angeles Dodgers
text: The Blue Jays rallied past the visiting Seattle Mariners, 4-3, in Game 7 of the American League Championship Series on Monday night.

alert_body: How Joe Rogan’s podcast with Mel Gibson led Florida to promise research into ivermectin as a cancer treatment
text: Ivermectin, an antiparasitic drug that gained fame as a possible covid treatment despite research showing its ineffectiveness, has taken on symbolic power in the backlash against traditional public health guidance that helped spawn the “Make America Healthy Again” movement.

alert_body: Futures of CNN and HBO at stake as Warner Bros. Discovery announces it’s open to a full or partial sale
text: The media company, which previously announced a plan to split its entertainment offerings from its sports and news programming, has decided to explore sale opportunities after receiving multiple bids. David Ellison, whose company Skydance recently took over Paramount, has reportedly expressed interest.

alert_body: North Carolina lawmakers vote to add GOP House seat, in win for Trump ahead of 2026 midterms
text: Republican state senators heeded President Donald Trump’s request to help protect the party’s narrow majority in next year’s elections. The state House is expected to sign off on the measure later this week. Gov. Josh Stein (D) does not have the power to veto it, leaving Democrats with few options but to sue.

alert_body: Trump-Putin meeting postponed after Russia’s top diplomat signaled a wide chasm between U.S. and Kremlin on Ukraine
text: The Trump administration said there are “no plans” for President Donald Trump and Russian President Vladimir Putin to meet in Hungary in the immediate future. The decision came after Russia’s foreign minister said Trump’s call for a ceasefire contradicted the understandings he reached with Putin.

text: If the Trump administration succeeds, almost all people admitted to the United States as refugees could be Afrikaners, a group not traditionally eligible for the program. The remainder may be chosen because of their ability to speak English or their views on “free speech,” people familiar with the matter said.

alert_body: Trump administration seeks to move special education to HHS as it works to close the Education Department

Education officials have floated the idea of moving special education to HHS, but the official who confirmed Tuesday that a move was being explored said there are multiple agencies involved in the discussions.

alert_body: New foreign student enrollment at U.S. colleges dropped 17 percent in the fall
text: The Trump administration has thrown up barriers to student visas, and experts expect a continued decline as many international students decide to study in other countries. The number applying to U.S. colleges for next year has dropped 9 percent so far, according to preliminary data. Some advocates argue the decline will hurt the U.S. economy because immigrants often play a key role in business start-ups and research.

alert_body: A Trump loyalist prosecutor is probing former top Obama administration officials
text:
Jason Reding Quiñones's appointment to lead an office he left last year after poor performance reviews is a case study in how the administration is operating U.S. attorney’s offices across the country, plucking Trump backers with little support from staffers to serve in high-powered positions, according to people familiar with the Justice Department’s operations. 

In several cases, including Reding Quiñones’s, the appointments have led to a staff exodus and a sharp drop in morale as the appointees embrace the administration’s most controversial investigations.

text: In the lawsuit filed in federal court in D.C., Kelly’s lawyers argued that the Pentagon’s inquiry, and formal reprimand, unlawfully violated the free speech rights of the retired Navy officer and due process. The lawsuit sharply escalates a confrontation between Kelly and Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth over a video reminding U.S. service members that they can refuse illegal orders.

alert_body: Trump announces 25 percent tariff on countries that trade with Iran
text: Tehran says it’s ready for “war” or dialogue as Washington weighed its response to mass protests against the government. The tariffs would mean higher prices for American importers of products from dozens of countries, including China, India, Russia, Turkey and Iraq.

alert_body: Minnesota and the Twin Cities sue DHS and ICE to halt immigration enforcement
text: Minnesota officials claim the Trump administration’s “unprecedented surge” of immigration agents is politically motivated and violates the U.S. Constitution. The state of Illinois filed a separate suit Monday seeking to place limits on Department of Homeland Security agents in the Chicago area.

alert_body: Which jobs have grown (and declined) fastest during your working life?
text: Here are the fastest-growing and fastest-shrinking jobs over the years, based on information from the Census Bureau’s Current Population Survey.

alert_body: Boat strike. Jerome Powell. ICE lawsuit. Transgender athletes. Rising emissions. Sick kids quiz. Decluttering tips. Catch up now.

alert_body: Price growth held firm in December, capping a year of persistent inflation
text: New government figures show that prices rose by 0.3 percent between November and December, in line with September’s reading of 0.3 percent. Overall, prices were 2.7 percent higher than they were a year ago, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

alert_body: A new Golden Globe in today’s On the Record
text: Answer now to earn your Tuesday points.

alert_body: Scott Adams dies at 68. The ‘Dilbert’ creator drew criticism after he veered into far-right political terrain.
text: Years before the film “Office Space” and TV series “The Office” satirized the workplace on-screen, Adams’s comic strip poked fun at corporate jargon, managerial ineptitude and the indignities of life in the cubicle farm. “Dilbert” once ran in more than 2,000 newspapers, but publishers cut ties with its creator after he made racist comments on a YouTube live stream.

alert_body: Carolyn Hax: Is their single-mom commune idea too good to be true?
text: Carolyn Hax: Is their single-mom commune idea too good to be true?

alert_body: Iranian forces have killed at least 2,000 people in demonstration crackdown, rights group says, as Trump encourages protesters
text: President Donald Trump said “help is on its way” to anti-regime protesters in Iran and said its government will pay a “big price.” The warning came as human rights groups warned of an escalating death toll amid a nationwide communications blackout. The U.S.-based Human Rights Activists News Agency estimated that more than 2,000 protesters have been killed since the demonstrations began last month.

alert_body: I’ve waited for this electrifying moment in Iran for 10 years, Jason Rezaian writes
text: A decade after I was freed from Evin prison, protests are rocking Iran — and planning is vital.

alert_body: Supreme Court appears likely to uphold two states’ bans of trans athletes in women’s sports
text: The justices heard arguments on whether bans in West Virginia and Idaho violate the Constitution’s equal protection clause. The outcome of the pair of cases could determine what happens with similar laws in more than half the country.

alert_body: Mike Tomlin steps down as Pittsburgh Steelers coach after 19 seasons
text: The move comes a day after the Steelers’ 30-6 loss to the Houston Texans in the opening round of the AFC playoffs in Pittsburgh. The Steelers remain without a postseason victory since the 2016 season, even after signing quarterback Aaron Rodgers to a one-year contract last summer.

alert_body: Claudette Colvin dies at 86. She refused to give up her seat on a segregated Alabama bus 9 months before Rosa Parks made history.
text: Colvin’s arrest in 1955 inaugurated what the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. described as a pivotal period for Black people in Montgomery. She became a star witness in a civil rights case that reached the Supreme Court, which ordered an end to bus segregation in 1956.

alert_body: Top federal prosecutors in D.C. and Minneapolis leave amid turmoil over Minneapolis shooting probe
text: The departures followed demands by Justice Department leaders to investigate the widow of Renée Good, the 37-year-old woman killed last week in Minneapolis by an Immigration and Customs Enforcement officer, according to a person familiar with the resignations.

alert_body: New RFK Jr. pick for advisory panel: ‘I was not anti-vaccine. I am now.’
text: Two OB/GYNs appointed to the influential Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices have criticized vaccination during pregnancy and more broadly. One called the vaccine industry “disgusting.”

alert_body: Saks Global — parent company of Saks Fifth Avenue, Neiman Marcus and Bergdorf Goodman — files for bankruptcy
text: Saks Global has faced declining sales and crushing debt. The holding company commenced voluntary Chapter 11 cases in the U.S. Bankruptcy Court for the Southern District of Texas, it said in a news release. Its stores remain open, it added.

alert_body: Trump reiterates Greenland’s importance before meeting Vance will host with officials from Denmark and the self-governing territory
text: Visiting officials appeared unnerved by the vice president’s planned involvement in today’s talks after they had sought a meeting with Secretary of State Marco Rubio.
